questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient presents to your clinic with an obvious deformity of his left upper limb. His past history is significant for a fracture of the left elbow for which he did not receive appropriate treatment. The following image shows a deformity as a result of a fracture. Which among the following complaints is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Anaesthesia over tip of little finger

questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the image above is cubitus valgus on the left side. It can affect the ulnar nerve leading to anesthesia at the tip of the little finger.

Cubitus valgus is a late complication of nonunion of fracture of lateral condyle of the humerus.  It can lead to late-onset ulnar palsy also called tardy ulnar nerve palsy. This can cause anesthesia at the tip of the little finger, which is the zone of autonomous supply of the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with widely distributed flaccid bullae. Histopathology shows a suprabasal acantholytic blister with superficial dermal infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence for immunoglobulin IgG is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding of bullae and the given histological features with a characteristic fish-net appearance in the immunofluorescence assay seen in the image are highly suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins (predominantly desmoglein 3). 

In pemphigus vulgaris, the location of the target antigen is intraepithelial. The bullae (blisters) of pemphigus vulgaris occur due to the destruction within the epidermis. Flaccid blisters are filled with clear fluid and may rupture, producing painful erosions.

This fish-net appearance of pemphigus vulgaris is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 > Dsg1), which are present intercellularly. Direct immunofluorescence of skin samples with anti-IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis.

It occurs most commonly in middle-aged women, and the most common presentation of pemphigus vulgaris is oral lesions. Cutaneous lesions develop later, with lesions occuring most commonly on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back. 

They also show a positive Nikolsky sign, which is peeling off of the epidermis even on slight rubbing of the skin.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase

questions.text: A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhea and mucocutaneous lesions as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. How will you treat this child?
questions.solution:
A child with eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region and diarrhea is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency and causes an inability to absorb sufficient zinc from the diet. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred management.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to a defect in intestinal zinc-specific transporter – Human ZIP4 protein. The genetic locus is on chromosome 8q24.3. It classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk. The symptoms are perioral and perineal rashes, periungual dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, and alopecia.

Investigations would reveal low serum zinc and paneth cell inclusion is seen in the intestinal mucosal biopsy. 

Treatment – Zinc – 50mg/ day for infants, upto 150mg/day for children

questions.text: A patient sustained a stab injury to his chest. The artery marked in the image given below is suspected to be injured. All of the following arteries may be compromised in this case, except ____
questions.solution:
The artery marked in the image in the internal thoracic artery and posterior intercostal arteries are not branches of the internal thoracic artery.

There are 11 pairs of posterior intercostal arteries. The first 2 pairs are branches of the superior intercostal artery, a branch of the costocervical trunk. They are distributed to upper 2 intercostal spaces.  The lower 9 pairs are branches of the descending thoracic aorta and are distributed to the lower 9 intercostal spaces.

The branches of the internal thoracic artery are:

  • Anterior intercostal arteries for the first 6 intercostal spaces.
  • Terminal branches at the level of the 6th intercostal space:
    • Superior epigastric artery
    • Musculophrenic artery
  • Sternal branches to:
    • Transversus thoracis muscle
    • Periosteum of the posterior sternal surface
    • Sternal red bone marrow
  • Perforating branches that pierce and supply pectoralis major and then become direct cutaneous vessels that supply the skin.

questions.text: A construction worker fell from a height with his arm in a flexed and adducted position. He is now unable to move his shoulder due to severe pain. An X-ray of his shoulder is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Aneurysmal bone cyst with hairline fracture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the “Light bulb” sign in the X-ray is suggestive of posterior dislocation of the shoulder.

In the posterior dislocation of the shoulder, the humerus is rotated internally. This causes changes to the normal radiographic contour of the head of the humerus. The humerus appears similar to a lightbulb in AP views.

Mechanism of injury: occurs most commonly during a convulsion, or after an electric shock. It can also happen after a fall on the flexed, adducted arm, either by a direct blow to the front of the shoulder or due to a fall on the outstretched hand.

Other radiological signs described in posterior dislocation of the shoulder in the AP view are as follows:

  • The rim sign: Widening of the glenohumeral joint space > 6 mm.
  • The vacant glenoid sign: The glenoid fossa looks empty as the humeral head has moved away from it.
  • The trough sign: A vertical line is seen on the anteromedial part of the humeral head due to the impression fracture by the glenoid labrum.

questions.text: A teenage boy presents with the following finding. He says that many of his family members also have the same complaint. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Fluoride excess is responsible for dental fluorosis, which presents as the mottling of teeth shown in the image.

Fluorosis is caused by excess fluoride in drinking water. It causes dental and skeletal fluorosis. It can also cause osteosclerosis. Accepted levels of fluoride in drinking water in India are 0.5- 0.8 mg/L. Fluorine is an essential element for the normal mineralization of bones and the formation of dental enamel. The two principal sources of fluorine are drinking water and foods such as sea fish and cheese.

Other options:

Option B: Fluoride deficiency leads to dental caries.

Option C: Zinc excess can result in reduced copper absorption, gastritis, fever, nausea, and vomiting. Occupational zinc exposure in excess can lead to pulmonary fibrosis.

Option D: Zinc deficiency causes growth failure and delayed wound healing. It is also associated with alopecia, dermatitis, and diarrhea.

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text:
You are assisting your senior in fetal cardiac surgery. He asks you to identify vessels A and B.

View of the heart from below upwards.

choices.text: A- Pulmonary vein, B- Pulmonary artery
A- Pulmonary artery, B- Pulmonary vein

questions.solution:
The vessel 'A' is aorta and 'B' is pulmonary artery in the given image. The aorta lies anterior and right to the pulmonary artery. Posterior and right to aortic opening lies the opening of superior vena cava.

The image below shows the posterior view of the heart demonstrating openings of major vessels in heart.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was examined in a village camp. The child had a poor appetite and visible peripheral edema. The hair was sparse and easily pluckable. The skin showed peeling as depicted below.  What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is kwashiorkor. The above clinical vignette and the image showing flaky paint dermatosis are seen characteristically in kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor results due to severe protein and essential amino acid deprivation along with adequate calorie intake. It is particularly seen in children at the time of weaning, to a diet consisting majorly of corn, rice, or beans. 

The clinical features include a classic cutaneous finding of diffuse reddish-brown scaling dermatosis that has been likened to cracked skin, peeling paint, enamel paint, flaky paint, or crazy paving. This is due to the typical scaling and irregular fissuring. Nails are thin and soft. Hairs are thin and sparse and display a flag sign consisting of alternative light and dark bands of hair. The consistent feature is the peripheral edema due to the associated hypoproteinaemia. Edema of the face results in moon facies. Abdominal distention (pot belly) is a feature and is due to hepatomegaly from increased fatty deposition due to a lack of available apolipoproteins.

Other options:

Option A: Marasmus results due to global macro-nutrient deficiency, which leads to growth retardation with <60% of ideal body weight. Loss of subcutaneous tissue, growth stunting, dyspigmentation, and desquamative changes are seen in these patients. Marasmus patients do not demonstrate hypoproteinaemia or edema. There is distension of the abdomen due to hypotonia of the abdominal musculature. These patients typically have wrinkled, loose, and dry skin. The hair and nails often grow slowly and may show brittleness. The hair falls out easily and often shows features of alopecia.

Below is the image of a child with marasmus.

Option B: Pellagra results from a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). It is characterized by the classic presentation of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck, which is a characteristic feature seen in pellagra.

Below is the image showing Casal's necklace.

Option C: Vitamin A deficiency can result in phrynoderma that is characterized by keratotic follicular papules along the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral arms. It is seen in the deficiency of vitamin B complex, C, E, and essential fatty acids as well.

Below is the image showing phrynoderma.

questions.text: A cervical mucus study was done on a 23-year-old woman. The microscopic picture appears as given below. Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: It is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus
Progesterone causes loss of this pattern
Persistence of this pattern indicates ovulation
This pattern is a part of the Insler scoring system

questions.solution:
The image shows a specimen of dried cervical mucus showing a charectaristic pattern of fern formation termed ferning. It occurs under the influence of estrogen. Ferning disappears after ovulation

Fern test:

A drop of cervical mucus is spread and dried on a glass slide and observed under the low-power microscope. 

In the preovulatory (oestrogenic) phase, a characteristic pattern of fern formation is observed due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the oestrogenic effect.

Following ovulation, ferning disappears due to progesterone activity. The disappearance of ferning is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.

Insler devised a scoring system by just taking into account various properties of cervical mucus such as amount, ferning, viscosity, etc. as an inexpensive test of ovulation.

questions.text: Below is a diagram depicting the natural history of the disease. Which point marks the onset of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Point C represents a point where signs and symptoms appear.

Various points marked in the image represent the following:

Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms.

Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 65-year-old man is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a solitary punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim with a beveled edge appearance, along with the age of the patient with history of normal hematological and urinary tests is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions. It can also infiltrate the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presents to you with multiple joint pains for the past 6 years. On examination, you notice the following deformity over the fingers. What is this deformity known as?
questions.solution:
The given deformity is a swan-neck deformity, seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It is characterized by hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). It occurs due to imbalance of extensor versus flexor action at the PIP joint, and laxity of the palmar plate.

Other deformities in RA:

  • Boutonniere deformity: Hyperextension of DIP joints and flexion at PIP joints
  • Z deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits.
  • Subluxation of MCP joints, with subluxation, or the partial dislocation of the proximal phalanx to the volar side of the hand leads to ulnar deviation
  • Inflammation of the ulnar styloid and tenosynovitis of the extensor carpi ulnaris causes distal ulna subluxation that results in the "piano key movement" of the ulnar styloid
  • Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), Hallux valgus, hammer toe
  • A flat foot occurs due to chronic inflammation of the ankle and midtarsal regions.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common

questions.text: A 39-year-old male undergoes a diagnostic work-up for backache; his X-ray is given below. What is the most common ocular manifestation that you would expect to see in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows bamboo spine, which is seen in ankylosing spondylitis. The most common ocular condition in ankylosing spondylitis is anterior uveitis. It is also the most common extraarticular manifestation in ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints commonly seen in young males. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. The progressive inflammatory granulation tissue in the spine in the paravertebral connective tissue leads to the bamboo spine.

Other extra-articular manifestations of AS:

  • Ocular: Iritis, conjunctivitis (reactive arthritis)
  • Cardiovascular: Valvular heart disease, aortitis, heart block
  • Neurologic: C1-C2 subluxation, cauda equina syndrome
  • GIT: Colitis, inflammatory bowel disease
  • Respiratory: Restrictive lung disease, upper lobe fibrosis

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious in onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at the age of <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for more than three months 

Examination findings:

There is a loss of normal lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion. Other findings :

  • Positive Fleche's test - It is done to assess cervical spine involvement. The patient is asked to touch the wall with the back of the head without raising the chin.
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement such as the pump-handle test, pelvic compression test, and Fabre’s test.
  • Schober’s test: It is used to detect reduced flexion of the spine. The test involves marking two points—one 10 cm above and one 5 cm below the level of the lumbosacral junction of the patient. The patient is then asked to bend forward, and the distance between the two points is measured. This distance normally increases by ≥5 cm. An increase of <4 cm indicates reduced flexion.

In the image below, the distance increases by 5 cm which is normal.

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker presented with complaints of cough, increased thirst, and increased urination.Chest X-ray revealed a central mass arising in the right lung field.  After the initial workup, he is diagnosed to have the paraneoplastic syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). FNAC of the tumor is done as shown. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The following image shows basophilic cells with salt and pepper chromatin. It is likely a case of small cell carcinoma lung. Confirmation can be done by IHC and detection of neurosecretory granules in the cells 

Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. It resolves within a month of initiation of chemotherapy.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

  • Lung
  • Duodenum

questions.text: A 40-year-old taxi driver presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the attitude of the limb that you would have seen in the examination, considering the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the condition given in the X-ray is posterior dislocation of the left hip joint. On physical examination, the affected limb will be adducted and internally rotated, which is also evident in the X Ray.

The radiograph in left posterior hip dislocation will have the following findings:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The left femoral head appears slightly smaller than the right femoral head
  • The limb is adducted and internally rotated, and hence the lesser trochanter is often obscured/less prominent on AP view.

Posterior dislocation of the hip joint commonly occurs with the dashboard injury. It is more common than an anterior hip dislocation. Shortening of the limb is seen in the posterior type.

As the sciatic nerve lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum, it may be damaged with posterior dislocation of the hip.

Methods of closed reduction for posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Allis manoeuvre
  • Stimson manoeuvre
  • East Baltimore lift manoeuvre
  • Bigelow manoeuvre 

In the majority of the cases of posterior hip dislocation, within 6 hours, a closed reduction under general anaesthesia is performed. However, if the reduction is not achieved after two or three attempts, or a CT scan shows the presence of intra-articular bone fragments or larger femoral headpieces that are incompletely reduced, open reduction should be performed.

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient presents with recurrent epigastric pain, weight loss, and diarrhea. On investigation, his serum protein level was found to be low. An endoscopy was done, and an image obtained when the scope was in the stomach is shown below. The gastric aspirate showed a decrease in the acid content of the stomach. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds, which are characteristic of Menetrier disease.

Menetrier disease is characterized by gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, protein-losing gastropathy, and hypochlorhydria.

This disease is caused by the overexpression of TGF- alpha, which increases the growth of mucous cells. The increased number of mucous cells leads to giant rugal folds. The resulting excessive production of mucous in the stomach causes an increased loss of proteins and chloride from the body.

Patients with Menetrier disease usually present with diarrhea, hypoproteinemia, and anemia.

Some patients may respond to cetuximab (a monoclonal antibody against EGFR). Severe cases require a gastrectomy.

Gastric antral vascular ectasia (option C) shows the presence of parallel red stripes over the gastric mucosa (watermelon stomach).

questions.text: Rajesh, a construction worker presented with redness and watery eyes. He was started on topical steroids for allergic conjunctivitis. 4 months later, he presents with similar complaints. Fluorescein staining revealed the following finding. Identify the lesion?
questions.solution:
The above lesion is a geographic ulcer. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus.

Most ocular disease is thought to represent HSV reactivation rather than primary infection. Several risk factors have been identified such as UV exposure, immunosuppression, drugs like steroids, prostaglandins and ocular surgery.

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with a sudden increase in the lesions given in the image. Which of the following should be suspected?
questions.solution:
The finding seen in the case scenario provided is seborrheic keratosis and this is highly suggestive of a visceral malignancy.

A sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses in association with skin tags and acanthosis nigricans has been associated with a variety of malignancies, including gastrointestinal and lung cancers; it is also known as the Leser-Trélat sign.

Seborrheic keratoses are common epidermal tumors consisting of a benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes. They present as well-demarcated, round or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface and a typical stuck-on appearance.

questions.text: A 43-year-old diabetic woman notices that on the extension of her fingers, the middle finger requires extra force to extend and snaps while doing so. There is an audible click when the finger is flexed. The extension is as depicted below. This is caused due to the involvement of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the video is a trigger finger which involves the flexor tendon.

Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon that prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect. The nodule can get trapped behind the A1 pulley leading to a locking of the finger in flexion.

Surgical treatment involves the release of the A1 pulley, which is thickened and fibrosed. Early cases may be treated with a steroid injection into the tendon sheath.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: The procedure done with the needle shown below is not contraindicated in

choices.text: A 1 year old child with seizures and overlying soft tissue infection over lumbar puncture site
A 20 year old patient with a posterior fossa mass
A 60 year old male with prosthetic heart valve on anticoagulants
A 30 year old primi gravida carrying twins

questions.solution:
The above image shows a Lumbar puncture needle. Pregnancy is not a contraindication for lumbar puncture.

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Thrombocytopenia or other bleeding diatheses (including ongoing anticoagulant therapy).
  • Possible raised intracranial pressure.
  • Suspected spinal epidural abscess or overlying soft tissue infection

questions.text: A patient presents with the following skin lesion. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a skin lesion that is red, edematous, and well-demarcated from the surrounding skin. These features are suggestive of erysipelas. 

Erysipelas is a skin infection involving superficial lymphatics. It is caused by streptococcus. It presents as erythematous, indurated, and inflamed skin lesions.

Other options:

Option B: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by the exfoliative toxin and presents with peeling of the affected skin.

Option C: Necrotizing fasciitis is a streptococcal infection involving the fascial planes. The lesions show dark areas of necrosis along with erythema.

Option D: Gas gangrene is a form of myonecrosis. It is a bacterial infection in which tissue gas is produced in gangrene. It is usually caused by Clostridium perfringens. The given image of gas gangrene shows necrotic bullae, erythema, and edema:

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, swelling of knee joints and non-blanching palpable purpura on the legs. His platelet levels are normal and his urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. An immunofluorescence study of his skin biopsy is given below.  What is the immunoglobulin commonly involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence study of the skin biopsy showing IgA and C3 deposition in the superficial capillaries of the skin is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura. The immunoglobulin commonly involved in the pathogenesis of this condition is IgA. 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, is a common small vessel vasculitis affecting children of 3-8 years of age. It is a type III hypersensitivity reaction characterised by the deposition of IgA in the small vessels of the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney, resulting in vasculitis.

The exact etiology of HSP remains unknown. But, it usually occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection caused by group A Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, Mycoplasma, and Adenovirus.

Clinical features of HSP include: 

  • Palpable purpura is symmetric and occurs in the lower extremities, extensor aspect of the upper limbs, and buttocks
  • Arthralgia and arthritis - commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints
  • Gastrointestinal manifestations - abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and intussusception
  • Renal manifestations - microscopic hematuria, hypertension, and progressive glomerulonephritis

The image given below shows palpable purpura in the lower limbs seen in HSP.

Laboratory findings seen in HSP are nonspecific and include leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, mild anemia, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). The platelet count is usually normal. A skin biopsy specimen can be useful in confirming leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence. Rarely, IgG and IgM deposits may also be seen.

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are used for the treatment of gastrointestinal manifestations in HSP. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with a testicular swelling was operated upon and the tumor was removed. HPE of the tumor is as given below. All are true regarding the given condition except:

choices.text: Metastasis is mainly through the lymphatics
Percutaneous testicular biopsy is ideal for confirmation
The tumor is removed by high inguinal orchidectomy

questions.solution:
The histopathology is diagnostic of testicular seminoma. The biopsy increases the risk of the spread of the cancer cells to the scrotum. Therefore, a biopsy should not be done on the suspected testicular tumors. Inguinal orchiectomy is done in such cases.

The histopathological examination of seminoma shows sheets of uniform tumor cells divided into poorly demarcated lobules by fibrous septa. Each cell is large, round, and has a distinct cell membrane, abundant clear cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus with a few nucleoli.

Seminoma is the most common testicular tumor. It is common in men between 20-40 years of age.

The patients usually present with a painless testicular lump. If a testicular tumor is suspected, blood samples are taken from the patient for the evaluation of the tumor markers (hCG, LDH, and AFP), and the diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound scanning of the testis. A high inguinal orchidectomy is performed.

Further treatment of seminoma depends on the stage of the tumor. Stage I tumors, whose levels of tumor markers decline after orchidectomy may not require further treatment. Stage II-IV tumors require radiotherapy and chemotherapy. The chemotherapeutic agents used are bleomycin, etoposide, and platin based agents (BEP).

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department one hour after the spillage of hot oil on his hands while cooking. On examination, multiple burn injuries are present on his right hand as shown in the image. The injuries are extremely painful when touched with gloves and the capillary refilling is normal.  You would classify this as a
questions.solution:
The degree of burns is second-degree superficial burn. The points that favor the diagnosis are the presence of multiple blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, and the normal capillary refilling time.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns): In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided as superficial or deep.
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to epidermis, dermis and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing the following procedure for the removal of gallstones. However, it required multiple attempts to retrieve the stone. What is the commonest complication expected in such cases after the procedure?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the procedure of Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreatography (ERCP). Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP. The Pancreatitis is usually mild and resolves in a few days.

Multiple attempts at cannulation, sphincter of Oddi dysfunction or history of recurrent pancreatitis and therapeutic procedures instead of diagnostic ones impart a higher risk of pancreatitis

In this procedure, a side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. Minor procedures like biopsy and endoscopic stone removal can be done via this itself.

Other investigations which might cause confusion in identification are those of :

MRCP (image below)

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiopancreatography (image below)

questions.text: A 22-year-old female getting evaluated for infertility undergoes the following investigation. The anomaly that is noted is:
questions.solution:
The anomaly seen is septate uterus. It occurs due to a persistence of septum between the two fused mullerian ducts.

Hysterosalpingography provides information about the interior of the uterine cavity and not the exterior. Therefore, it cannot differentiate between a septate uterus and a bicornuate uterus. A septate uterus has a smooth fundal contour whereas a bicornuate uterus has an indented fundus.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery

  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery

  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing for 2 months. He mentions that he is taking hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He works at a cement manufacturing factory. Otoscopy findings are normal. Rinne’s test result is positive in both ears. Audiometry results are shown below. What is the likely cause of his hearing loss?
questions.solution:
The pure-tone audiogram shown in the given image shows an acoustic dip at 4000 Hz, which is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss. 

The patient's employment history (working at a cement factory) suggests constant exposure to loud noise. Positive Rinne's test result in both ears suggests that air conduction is better than bone conduction, i.e. absence of conductive hearing loss or presence of sensorineural hearing loss.

Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120–155 dB, such as explosions and gunshots, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells in the organ of Corti. 

The patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in a noisy environment. This condition is irreversible and is managed with hearing aids. 

Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

Other options:

Option A: Medication adverse effects (ototoxicity) cause bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a downsloping audiogram, typically involving frequencies above 8,000 Hz and progresses to lower speech frequencies. Common drugs causing the same include aminoglycoside antibiotics, loop diuretics (not thiazides), antimalarials, cisplatin, and NSAIDs like ibuprofen, salicylates, and indomethacin.

Option B: Otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Pure-tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000 Hz, which is known as Carhart's notch. There is a loss of air conduction in the lower frequencies.

The audiogram given below shows Carhart's notch, which is seen in otosclerosis.

Option D: Presbycusis is a physiological sensorineural hearing loss occurring in individuals above 65 years of age. Audiometry shows a downsloping graph.

World Hearing Day is celebrated on March 3, 2022. Globally, over one billion people are at risk of hearing loss due to loud volumes for long periods. Hearing loss caused by loud sounds is permanent; however, it is also completely preventable. The theme for this year's campaign is "To hear for life, listen with care"

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient presents to your clinic with complaints of mildly itchy, multiple rash-like lesions on the back since two weeks. He says that it was preceded by a single large patchy lesion on his lower back. An image of the physical examination findings is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is pityriasis rosea, which has typical collarette scales. A collarette scale is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion.

Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults. It is characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms. It is also called pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal.

The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch. Christmas tree pattern along cleavage lines with the peripheral collarette of scale producing the hanging curtain sign is also seen. 

Note: Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated stratum corneum.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (ichthyos - fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to the reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Mica-like scales

They are seen in Pityriasis lichenoides. The lesions are polymorphic with some showing hemorrhagic crusting and adherent scales.

Yellow / greasy scales

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scales

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis versicolor

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presented with difficulty in reading and blurring of vision in both eyes. On evaluation, her visual acuity and fundus examination were normal. Her visual field charting showed a defect as shown below. Where is the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect shown in the image is bitemporal hemianopia. The site of the lesion is the optic chiasma due to the decussation of nasal fibres.

Optic chiasm lesions may produce the following visual field defects

  • Bitemporal hemianopia in case of medial optic chiasm lesions.
  • Binasal hemianopia in case of lateral optic chiasm lesions.

Other notable visual field defects are

  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
    • Pie-in-the-sky defects
    • Involvement of Meyer’s loop - inferior fibres of optic radiations
    • Contralateral temporal lobe
  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
    • Pie-in-the-floor defects
    • Involvement of Baum’s loop - superior fibres of optic radiations
    • Contralateral parietal lobe
  • Homonymous hemianopia
    • Involvement of retrochiasmal regions such as optic tract, geniculate body, and optic radiations.
    • Sparing of the macula and more congruous field defect (both sides have the same extent of field loss) when the occipital cortex is involved.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Raju, a truck driver, presented with complaints of cloudy vision while driving at night for the past couple of months. On examination, his eyes had the following appearance. Which among the following underlying conditions is the most likely cause for his vision problems?
questions.solution:
The image shows a snowstorm appearance or a snowflake cataract. This is characteristic of diabetes mellitus.

Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract

Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract

Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: An elderly woman was hospitalized for pneumonia and is on antibiotic therapy with clindamycin. She now complains of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Her colonoscopy findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following toxins is most commonly associated with her GI symptoms?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image given above showing yellow plaques and nodules on the mucosa are suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis. It is usually caused by Clostridium difficile. The pathogenesis is mediated by the enterotoxins - toxin A and toxin B.

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers. It can persist on surfaces for months. Risk factors include poor hand hygiene, old age, and gastrointestinal surgery.

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins—toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic. 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: An elderly man presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food for the past 7 months. He also complains of a feeling of food getting stuck in his throat. Serial images of barium swallow are given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It occurs between the oblique and horizontal fibres of inferior constrictor

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the barium swallow images are suggestive of Zenker’s diverticulum, which is a false diverticulum.

A true diverticulum involves all the layers (mucosa, submucosa, muscularis). Since Zenker's diverticulum involves only the mucosa coming out through Killian's dehiscence, it is considered a false type of diverticulum. Furthermore, it is a pulsion type of diverticulum — that is, it develops due to the high pressure present inside the pharynx and not due to any pulling force from the outside.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presented with pain in the right knee region for the past three months. On examination, the right knee region is swollen and there is a reduced range of motion. An x-ray taken for further evaluation reveals the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray showing an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular soap bubble appearance is suggestive of Giant cell tumor (GCT) or Osteoclastoma.

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years with slight female predominance. It is seen exclusively in adults and affects the epiphysis of long bones, commonly in the distal end of the femur followed by the proximal tibia. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

  • Important x-ray features of a GCT
    • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
    • Eccentric location, most often subchondral.
    • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
    • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.
    • No calcification within the tumor.
    • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

Other options:

Option A: Aneurysmal bone cyst is a benign, expansile lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the long bones, comprised of blood-filled cystic spaces. It is more common in the age group of 5-20 years. These occur more commonly in the metaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, and humerus. Patients usually present with pain and swelling. The x-ray image is given below:

 

Option B: Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. Radiograph and MRI would reveal pedunculated bony protuberance with a stalk with a growing cartilaginous cap (as shown below) or some lesions with a broad sessile base.

 

Option D: Osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance (as shown below) on the X-ray.

Related Pearl: Classical Radiological Appearance of Bone Tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance / Codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion)

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis)

Soap bubble appearance 

Giant cell tumor, adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance / Shepherd's

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors (chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn, punctate or comma-shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Stippled or Punctate calcification

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors (osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment / Trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double-density fluid levels and intra-lesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Winking owl sign

Vertebral metastasis 

Polka dot sign / Corduroy / Jailhouse sign

Vertebral hemangioma

Moth eaten bone

Multiple myeloma

Related Pearl: Most common sites of primary bone tumors

EPIPHYSEAL :

  • Chondroblastoma 
  • Giant cell tumor in adults
  • Articular osteochondroma (trevor’s disease)
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma 

DIAPHYSEAL:

  • Round cell lesions-Ewing’s sarcoma 
  • Lymphoma
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Adamantinoma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Histiocytosis
  • Osteoblastoma

METAPHYSEAL:

  • Chondrosarcoma (Note:Clear cell chondrosarcoma is epiphyseal)
  • Enchondroma
  • Osteochondroma
  • Bone cyst
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Giant cell tumor in children

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presents with a sudden onset stabbing pain followed by diffuse abdominal pain and distension. He has a history of burning epigastric pain that is relieved by eating, and nocturnal pain for the past 5 months. His abdominal X-ray is as shown below. Which among the following is not associated with the pathology depicted in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with abdominal pain and distension and erect x-ray showing air under the diaphragm is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum due to duodenal perforation. Spinnaker sail sign is not seen in pneumoperitoneum.

The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails.

The other signs mentioned above are seen in the pneumoperitoneum caused due to hollow viscus perforation.

Duodenal perforation characterized by a sudden, sharp, stabbing pain is a known complication of peptic ulcer disease suggested by this patient’s history. The erect X-ray in pneumoperitoneum shows gas under the diaphragm. Other signs can be further divided into anatomical compartments in relation to the pneumoperitoneum:

Bowel related signs-

  • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign or bas-relief sign) - 50% of the cases have gas in the right upper quadrant adjacent to the liver, lying mainly in the subhepatic space and the hepatorenal fossa (Morrison’s pouch). When both the outer and inner walls of a bowel loop are visualized, it is known as Rigler’s sign.
  • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign) - The formation of a radiolucent triangle of gas around three bowel loops or two bowel loops and the abdominal wall. 

Peritoneal ligament related signs-

  • Football sign
  • Falciform ligament sign
  • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - It is visualized in the pelvis as a result of the free gas outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments.

Right upper quadrant sign-

  • Morison's pouch sign (doge cap sign) - Air in the Morison pouch, bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant, presents as either a triangular-shaped, crescentic or semicircular lucency.
  • Cupola sign

The radiograph below shows a supine abdominal X-ray of a neonate with a large pneumoperitoneum. An oval lucency divided by the falciform ligament resulting in the so-called football sign is seen on supine film.

Given below is the supine abdominal radiograph of a patient showing pneumoperitoneum and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign.

Gas that rises within the abdominal cavity of the supine patient to accumulate underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline. It is seen as lucency overlying the lower thoracic vertebral bodies. This is called the cupola sign. 

Supine abdomial X-ray given below shows cupola sign.

questions.text: A 31-year-old G3P1 female who has come to the AN clinic as part of her routine antenatal visit undergoes a sonogram.  Identify the finding from her umbilical artery doppler image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image represents an absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical arteries which indicates poor perinatal outcome.

A: Normal diastolic flow.

B: Absence of end-diastolic flow seen in IUGR.

C: Reversal of end-diastolic flow seen in impending IUD.

Umbilical artery vessels are characterized by forward, low resistance flow. As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices, so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases. S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

  • Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)
  • Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise (hence terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks)
  • Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death (terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age)

The middle cerebral artery detects fetal anemia.

Note: Increased fetal diastolic flow in the middle cerebral artery with the absent diastolic flow in the aorta implies fetal acidemia

questions.text: A farmer presents with lesions on his hand as seen in the image below. He gives a history of a thorn prick a few days ago. Histological examination of the lesion showed sclerotic bodies. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing warty lesions on the hand and the presence of sclerotic bodies suggests the diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a type of subcutaneous mycoses caused by fungi of the genus Fonsecae and Cladophialophora. It can cause different patterns of lesions like verrucous, nodular, cicatricial, ulcerated, and tumorous.

The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of yeast-like sclerotic bodies on KOH mount or by culture on Sabouraud agar.

The image given below shows sclerotic bodies seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man involved in a fight injured his finger, and the deformity is as shown in the following image. You would suspect the diagnosis to be Mallet finger if you find the X-ray showing _________
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history of trauma and flexion at the DIP as seen in the clinical image, the diagnosis is mallet finger. It is due to the avulsion of the extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint by hyperflexion injury. As it occurs due to soft tissue injury, a radiograph will not show any bony abnormality, unless it is associated with an avulsion fracture.

It is treated by splinting the finger in hyperextension.

Jersey finger is caused by the rupture of flexor digitorum profundus from the distal phalanx. It occurs when there is hyperextension of the flexed finger trapped in a jersey.On Physical exam, finger lies in slight extension relative to other fingers in resting position and no active flexion of DIP is possible.

The following image shows splinting of the mallet finger.

Mallet finger is commonly known as baseball finger because the injury often happens when playing baseball.

Damage to the tendon occurs when a hard ball (that you’re trying to catch or field) hits your fingertip.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man working in the mining industry comes with complaints of dyspnea.  A chest X-ray showed eggshell calcification in the hilar lymph nodes and the CT scan of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 42-year-old man who works in the mining industry presenting with complaints of dyspnea, chest X-ray showing eggshell calcification of the hilar lymph nodes and the given CT showing a “crazy paving pattern” is suggestive of silicosis.

Silicosis is an occupational disease caused by exposure to silica or crystalline quartz. It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying.

Silicosis presents as small rounded opacities in the upper lobe. There may be calcification of hilar lymph nodes which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern due to interlobular septal thickening on the background of ground-glass opacity.

Other options:

Option A:  Asbestosis is an occupational disease and is characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lung due to asbestos exposure. It is seen in people who work in shipbuilding, processing, construction, and mining industries. Irregular or linear opacities are usually noted in the lower lung fields and are the radiographic hallmark of asbestosis. HRCT will show the presence of pleural plaque, and subpleural curvilinear lines that appear parallel to the pleura.

Option C: Berylliosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to beryllium. It is seen in people who work on processing alloys for high-tech industries. Chest radiography shows nodules along the septal lines with hilar and mediastinal lymph node enlargement. HRCT will show pulmonary nodules, diffuse interstitial fibrosis, and interlobular septal thickening. 

option D: Byssinosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to cotton dust as in textile and rope-making industries. Chest X-ray shows hyperlucency, diaphragmatic flattening, and emphysema. A chest CT demonstrates ground glass opacities largely distributed in the basal regions with centrilobular nodules. 

Related Pearl: Some common pneumoconiosis

Agent

Disease

Exposure

Anthracosis

Progressive massive fibrosis

Caplan syndrome

Coal mining (particularly hard coal)

Silica

Metal casting work, sandblasting, hard rock mining, stone cutting, others

Asbestos

Pleural plaques
Caplan syndrome

Carcinoma of the lung, larynx, stomach, colon

Mining, milling, manufacturing, and installation and removal of insulation

Mining, manufacturing
