Related Pearl: Eggshell calcification of lymph node on chest X-ray

Eggshell calcification refers to fine calcification seen at the periphery of a lymph node. Causes are -

  • Silicosis (most common)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Post-irradiation lymphoma
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Tuberculosis

questions.text: The image shows a graph plotted between the rate of reaction (on the y-axis) and substrate concentration (on the x-axis). Which of the following statements is not true regarding this plot?

choices.text: It is not seen with monomeric enzymes
The enzyme may have multiple binding sites

questions.solution:
Follows Michaelis Menten kinetics statement is not true regarding this plot. 

The given plot shows a sigmoid curve suggestive of cooperative binding of the enzymes to their substrates. This type of saturation kinetics is explained by Hill equation. 

Michaelis - Menten Kinetics:

The Michaelis - Menten equation gives the mathematical relationship between initial reaction velocity, v, and substrate concentration [S] which is as given below.

v = Vmax[S]/Km+[S]

where Km is the substrate concentration at which vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) which is reached at a particular concentration of the enzyme.

A graph showing a hyperbola is suggestive of Michaelis - Menten kinetics of the enzyme which is as follows.

For enzymes showing Michaelis - Menten kinetics, there is an increase in the rate of reaction, V, with an increase in substrate concentration till a point Vmax is reached beyond which rate of reaction shows saturation.

Hill equation:

Allosteric enzymes are those for which catalysis at the active site may be modulated by the presence of effectors at an allosteric site.

This is the exclusive property of multimeric enzymes, which have multiple binding sites for enzymes. This property is analogous to oxygen binding by haemoglobin. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes.

As Michaelis Menten equations cannot be used, the Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding.

Allosteric enzymes have one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition. The biopsy on the frozen section is given below. Which of the following mutations is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient from a hilly (iodine deficient) area and the biopsy specimen showing capsular invasion by tumor follicles confirms the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma. It is associated with RAS mutation.

Follicular carcinomas are associated with acquired mutations that activate RAS or the PI­3K/AKT arm of the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (PIK3CA gene).

PAX8-PPARG fusion gene has been described in one-third to one-half of follicular carcinomas.

Note: TSHR and GNAS mutations are rare in follicular carcinomas; thus, toxic adenomas and toxic multinodular goiter do not seem to be forerunners of malignancy.

RET and GNAS mutations are associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. Below is its histopathology image showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma.

BRAF mutations can be seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma and it's histopathology showing branched papillae with orphan Annie eye nuclei is shown below.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

Related Pearl: Gene alterations in thyroid cancer

Type of Thyroid Carcinoma  Mutations
Papillary Carcinoma

BRAF mutation

RET/PTC rearrangement

MET

NTRK1 fusion gene

GDNF - glial derived neurotropic factor
Follicular carcinoma  

RAS mutation

PIK3CA mutation

PTEN mutation

PAX8/PPAR1 fusion gene
Medullary carcinoma  RET mutation
Follicular adenoma  

TSH-R mutation

Gsα (GNAS) mutation

Ras mutation (<20% cases)

PAX8/PPARγ1 fusion (<10% cases)

PTEN

CTNNB1 (β-catenin)

questions.text: A dead body was found in an abandoned state in a forest. The postmortem changes in the body are shown in the image below. These changes are indicative of:
questions.solution:
The image above shows marbling which is an external sign of putrefaction.

In putrefaction, bacteria from the gut enter into and multiply in the surrounding tissues, eventually spreading through the blood vessels to other parts of the body. This chiefly occurs due to an increase in hydrogen ion concentration and a decrease in oxygen concentration in the tissues. A contributing factor would be the absence of the body's defensive mechanisms. 

The bacterium Clostridium welchii is largely responsible for the putrefactive changes spreading through the body, due to its production of the enzyme lecithinase.

The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying outside in the air is a greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.

The superficial veins of roots of the limb, thighs, sides of the abdomen, and shoulders are stained greenish-brown or purplish-red, in a linear branching pattern. This is called marbling and is usually prominent 36-48 hours after death occurs due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin formation subsequent to hemolysis of red blood cells.

Other options:

Option B: Joule burns or electric marks occur due to contact with electricity and are found at the point of entry of the current. They are observed as round or oval, shallow craters, having a ridge of skin around their circumference. The floor is lined with pale flattened skin. 

Option C: Filigree Burns are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on the skin that are indicative of a lightning strike. They resemble the branches of a tree and are usually found over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks.

Option D: Postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ livor mortis/ Suggilation refers to purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependent parts of the body.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with long-standing diabetes presents with complaints of lower backache. An x-ray image of her spine is given below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image represents rugger jersey spine which is characteristic of hyperparathyroidism seen in renal osteodystrophy.

Rugger jersey appearance is seen due to osteosclerosis of the superior and inferior vertebral endplates. This occurs due to excess osteoid formation by the osteoblasts to counteract increased bone resorption. The term 'rugger jersey’ appearance is used because there are alternating bands of increased and decreased bone density, similar to the jersey of a rugby player.


Radiographic changes in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Subperiosteal bone resorption: Classically affects the radial aspects of the proximal and middle phalanges of the second and third fingers
  • Terminal tuft erosion of phalanges (acroosteolysis)
  • Rugger Jersey spine
  • Osteopenia
  • Brown tumors
  • Salt and pepper sign in the skull (pepperpot skull)

Note: Paget's disease and osteopetrosis are potential differentials for rugger jersey spine but this term and pattern are distinctive for hyperparathyroidism. The clinical scenario with a history of long-standing diabetes makes the diagnosis of chronic kidney disease renal osteodystrophy more likely.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male comes with complaints of  Low Back Ache. Your orthopedics resident proceeds to examine him and during the process of examination,  with the patient in the position shown in the image below, you notice your ortho resident dorsiflexing the great toe. This is known as the ______
questions.solution:
The scenario indicates the examiner dorsiflexing the toes after doing SLRT. This produces pain due to stretching of the Sciatic nerve. It is called as Sicard test.
If instead of great toes, the whole foot is dorsiflexed, it is called the Bragard sign.

Important tests for intervertebral disc prolapse:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign

This is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area.  The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position. The affected leg is then passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. The examiner stops further leg elevation when pain is elicited. Normally it should be possible to raise the limb to 80–90 degrees. The SLRT test is positive if the patient develops pain when the leg is between 30 and 60/70 degrees from horizontal. The pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf.

2. Bragard test (or Sciatic stretch test or Flip test)

Perform SLRT. At the point where the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little. The stretching and pain become less. At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed. If the pain at the back of the thigh or in the calf is felt again, the test is positive. This is also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive.

3. Crossed SLRT (or well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign)

When SLRT is performed on the unaffected side, the patient may feel pain on the affected side. This is termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is a very specific sign of root compression. It becomes positive usually when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse.

4. Bowstring sign (or popliteal compression test)

The ‘bowstring sign’ is even more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee so as to relax the sciatic nerve (Buckling sign). Buttock pain is immediately relieved. The examiner then presses the popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. This will tighten the nerve like a bowstring and re-induce the pain. 

5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign)

The patient lies prone. The examiner flexes the knee to the thigh and the hip is passively extended. The test is positive if the patient experiences anterior thigh pain. This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions.

questions.text: A girl was brought by her parents with an itchy rash as shown in the image below. She also complains of difficulty in climbing stairs. A muscle biopsy reveals peri-fascicular atrophy. Immunohistochemistry revealed positive Myxovirus resistance protein A. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of Gottron's papules along with the history suggestive of proximal muscle weakness and the investigation findings are suggestive of dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy. It is characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations.  

The classic cutaneous features in dermatomyositis include:

  • Gottron’s sign - erythematous to violaceous rash that occur symmetrically over the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP)/ knuckle joints, elbows, knees, and ankles. Raised erythematous rash over the knuckles is pathognomic of dermatomyositis is called Gottron's papules.
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema
  • Shawl sign- macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • V sign - rash on the neck and chest in a V shaped manner due to sun exposure.
  • Poikiloderma - areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation, atrophy and telangiectasia
  • Nail fold changes
  • Mechanic's hands
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

In dermatomyositis, skeletal muscle weakness involves proximal muscles in a symmetric manner and the muscle biopsy shows peri-fascicular atrophy. However, the Myxovirus resistance protein A immunohistochemistry test is more specific than biopsy. A highly raised creatinine kinase can help in diagnosis as well.

The image below shows heliotrope rash:

The image below shows the shawl sign:

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis
Age of onset Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years  
Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No
Muscle involvement

Symmetric

Symmetric

Asymmetric
Histopathological Findings

Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates 

Perivascular infiltrates  

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: During casualty rotations, you see a  patient who suddenly went into apnea, being ventilated with the following apparatus. What does the part marked as A represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask and the part marked as A represents the oxygen inlet.

Bag and mask ventilation is used as the first step in airway management to provide positive pressure ventilation. It serves as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airways until tracheal intubation is achieved. 

The bag in this apparatus is a self-inflating bag. This allows for it to be used without a pressurized gas supply and is delivered to the patient when the bag is squeezed (compressed). A patent airway and a good seal are essential to facilitate bag and mask ventilation.

The face mask can be used by two techniques:

  • One-handed technique: Most commonly used technique. This is achieved by ensuring a tight seal with the left-hand thumb and index finger forming a 'C' around the collar of the mask. The third and fourth digits are placed on the ramus of the mandible, and the fifth digit placed below the angle of the mandible helps in jaw thrust.
  • Two-handed technique: This is used in cases of difficult airways and it requires assistance.

Signs of effective ventilation:

  • Chest rise on squeezing the bag
  • Condensation in the clear mask
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Capnography

Mask ventilation is usually contraindicated in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation. It should be used with caution in patients with severe facial trauma.

The following image shows the parts of a self-inflating bag and mask apparatus with a reservoir bag.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with irregular cycles and inability to conceive. On examination, she has facial acne and dense black hair on her upper lip. An image of the ultrasound of her ovaries is given below. She most likely has:
questions.solution:
The ultrasound shows multiple cysts in the ovaries and along with the given clinical symptoms suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is characterized by multiple small cysts in the ovaries usually of diameter 2–9 mm.

The Rotterdam criteria for the diagnosis of PCOS is the presence of two out of the following three:

  • Oligo and/or anovulation
  • Clinical and/or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism
  • Polycystic ovaries by ultrasound - ≧12 follicles in either ovary measuring 2-9 mm and/or ovarian volume > 10mL

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented with a deformity of the left arm as shown in the below image. It is due to the rupture of the tendon of:

choices.text: Long head of the biceps brachii muscle
Short head of the biceps brachii muscle

questions.solution:
The given image shows Popeye's sign. It occurs due to the rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii muscle.

Popeye sign appears due to the bulging of the muscle belly caused by contraction of the unrestrained muscles on flexing the elbow. The sign is named due to the resemblance of the deformity with the famous cartoon character 'Popeye'.

Biceps brachii is one of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm. It has two heads - a long head and the short head. The long head originates from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula whereas the short head originates from the apex of the coracoid process. Both heads get inserted into the radial tuberosity. 

The biceps brachii muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6). It causes powerful flexion of the forearm at the elbow joint and supination of the forearm. It also is an accessory flexor of the arm at the glenohumeral joint. 

The rupture of muscles and tendons of the upper limb is usually uncommon, however, the long head of biceps brachii is the most commonly ruptured tendon. The distal biceps tendon may also rupture and it is important to determine its exact site, as it will determine the surgical approach for repair. 

The brachialis is also a muscle in the anterior compartment of the arm. It originates from the anterior aspect of the humerus and inserts into the ulnar tuberosity. It is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6) and radial nerve (C7). It is a strong flexor of the forearm at the elbow joint. 

Related Pearl: Dermatome and root value of the upper limb

Key Sensory Areas:

  • C5 - Upper lateral part of arm
  • C6 - Palmar pad of thumb
  • C7 - Pad of index finger
  • C8 - Pad of little finger
  • T1 - Skin on medial aspect of elbow

questions.text: A 56-year-old hypertensive man presented with a 2-day history of continuous gnawing pain in the hypogastric region. An ultrasound revealed a pulsatile intra-abdominal mass. CT image is given below. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Follow up with serial abdominal ultrasound

questions.solution:
The image shows an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The next best in management in this case is operative repair as the patient is symptomatic.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms are mostly asymptomatic and are detected as incidental findings on investigations for other complaints. Sometimes, they present with pain and pulsatile abdominal mass. Rupture of aneurysm presents with acute pain and hypotension.

Management of abdominal aortic aneurysms:

  • Statins- Atherosclerosis is the most common pathology associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. Hence, statins are prescribed to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
  • Asymptomatic aneurysms <5.5 cm in diameter- serial abdominal ultrasound to monitor the rate of expansion of the aneurysm.
  • Operative repair is indicated for:
    • Aneurysm of any size associated with symptoms
    • Rapidly growing aneurysms
    • Aneurysms ≥5.5 cm in diameter

Note: Medical management with beta-blockers is not effective in reducing the rate of growth of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant female presents with hepatitis and personality changes. A picture of her eye has been provided below. Among the following options,  what drug should be used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The image provided above represents the Kayser-Fleischer ring which is seen in Wilson's disease. Zinc should be used in pregnant females with Wilson’s disease as it is essentially nontoxic. It produces a negative copper balance by blocking the intestinal absorption of copper, and it also induces hepatic metallothionein synthesis which sequesters additional toxic copper.

 Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. It is characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomic. It does not interfere with vision. It is present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms. However, the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Wilsons disease is an autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Sternlieb's criteria: Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Recommended Anticopper Drugs for Wilson's Disease

Disease Status First Choice Second Choice
Initial hepatic    

Hepatitis or Cirrhosis without decompensation

 Zinc Trientine
Hepatic decompensation    
Mild Trientine and Zinc Penicillamine and Zinc
Moderate Trientine and Zinc Hepatic transplantation
Severe Hepatic Transplantation Trientine and Zinc
Initial neurological/Psychiatric Tetrathiomolybdate and Zinc Zinc
Maintenance Zinc Trientine
Presymptomatic Zinc Trientine

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with increasing tiredness, bone aches, and bruising on his legs. Bone marrow aspirate shows the presence of characteristic cells as shown in the image below. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely to be detected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells. This is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) or AML associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17).

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is a type of AML.

Clinical features include anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia, most notably fatigue, fever, and spontaneous mucosal and cutaneous bleeding.

Bone marrow aspirate will show neoplastic promyelocytes with abnormally coarse and numerous azurophilic granules. 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia has a very good prognosis and is curable. The treatment of choice is all-trans-retinoic acid and arsenic trioxide.

Other options:

Option A: Inversion 16 is associated with AML M4 (myelomonocytic) and has a good prognosis.

Option C: Inversion 3 is associated with AML M7 (megakaryoblastic) and has a bad prognosis.

Option D: t(8;21) is associated with AML M2 (blasts with maturation) and has a good prognosis.

Related Pearl: Important Translocations in AML

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion

  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

questions.text: A young male patient presented with a high fever, muscle aches, and easy fatigability. He gives a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain about 20 days ago. His blood investigations revealed eosinophilia. His muscle biopsy findings are given in the image below. What is the most likely organism responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy findings showing encysted spiral larvae are characteristic of Trichinella spiralis.

Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents as diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

The larvae more commonly infect active muscles like the diaphragm, tongue, intercostals, extraocular muscles, etc. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months.

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

questions.text: In the image of the bacterial RNA polymerase given below, which subunit  enables RNA polymerase to recognize promoter regions on the DNA and thus helps to position it correctly on the template DNA?
questions.solution:
The σ subunit (sigma factor) enables RNA polymerase to recognize promoter regions on the DNA and thus helps to position it correctly on the template DNA. Thus, the σ subunit enables the core enzyme to recognize and bind the promoter region to form the preinitiation complex (PIC).

Following this, the RNA Polymerase catalyzes the formation of the first phosphodiester bond, and the nascent chain is attached to the polymerization site on the β subunit of RNA Polymerase. This reaction is termed initiation. The β subunit also binds to the Mg ion.

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

tRNA, 5srRNA

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child has thin extremities and  hepatomegaly. Investigations revealed hypoglycemia, elevated uric acid levels in the blood, and marked lactic acidosis. The blood sample has the following appearance. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia (milky white plasma), hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease (type Ia). It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase.

Signs and symptoms of von Gierke disease are

  • Seizures 
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Milky white plasma - due to very high serum triglyceride levels and cholesterol levels
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Enlarged kidney
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia (blood glucose <60 mg/dL)
  • Blood uric acid levels >5 mg/dL
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by nasogastric infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch.
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Oral citrate and bicarbonate administration.
  • HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors and fibrates therapy should be started if triglyceride levels are >900 mg/dL, despite dietary therapy.
  • Allopurinol (10 mg/kg/day) should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is assessing the personality of a patient by using a test with cards containing images. The first card of the set used in this test is similar to the image below. This test is a type of _____.
questions.solution:
The test given is of the Rorschach's inkblot test, which is a projective personality test that measures broad-band personality.

Rorschach's inkblot test:

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblots are shown to the participants. The test is administered in two phases:

  • Free association phase: participant's response to the cards is recorded
  • Inquiry phase: participants explain why they formed the impression.

Projective tests:

It is based on the principle that when presented with an ambiguous stimulus, such as an inkblot, the patient's responses will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality. The ambiguous stimulus is a sort of screen on which the individual projects his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Projective tests generally do not measure a particular personality type like 'Type-A personality'(Narrow-band measurement), but rather measures these as a 'whole'(Broad-band measurement)

Commonly used projective tests are:

  • Thematic apperception test
  • Rorschach's inkblot test
  • Sentence completion test
  • Draw a person test

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.

 

Sentence Completion Test

Uses Characteristics
Used to identify worries and problems using verbal associations

Projective test

Patients complete sentences started by the examiner

questions.text: A 21-year-old previously healthy athlete suffers a sudden cardiac arrest while playing a sport. On autopsy, it was found that there was hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The gene encoding for which of the following proteins is most commonly mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The gene encoding for β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC) proteins is most commonly mutated in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

HCM is a common autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy, abnormal diastolic filling (with preserved systolic function), and intermittent left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. It is the leading cause of unexplained left ventricular hypertrophy.

It is caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomeric proteins, including myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7). It can also rarely occur due to mutations in genes coding for cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin.

In HCM, myocardial hypertrophy occurs without ventricular dilation. Furthermore, there is asymmetric septal hypertrophy, where the ventricular septum is disproportionately thickened compared to the left ventricular free wall. The enlarged septum bulges into the ventricular cavity, giving it a banana-like shape. Hypertrophy is most marked in the subaortic region of the septum.

The most important histologic features in HCM are:

  • Massive myocyte hypertrophy
  • Myofiber disarray including that of myocyte bundles, individual myocytes, and contractile elements
  • Fibrotic narrowing of small intramural arteries
  • Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

The images below show normal cardiac myocytes and myofibril disarray in HCM, respectively:

 

Exertional dyspnea due to reduced cardiac output is seen, and a harsh systolic ejection murmur caused due to LVOT obstruction can be heard. Further, atrial fibrillation, stroke due to mural thrombus formation, and ventricular arrhythmias are common complications of HCM. 

β-adrenergic blockers can be used to decrease heart rate and contractility, and implantable cardioverter defibrillators are used for patients with ventricular arrhythmias.

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) occurs due to truncating mutations in the titin gene. The heart in DCM is flabby and hypo-contracting, in contrast with the thick-walled, heavy, and hyper-contracting heart in HCM. Histology reveals hypertrophied myocytes with hyperchromatic distorted nuclei with a ninja star-like appearance, as shown in the image below. Variable degrees of interstitial and endocardial fibrosis is also present.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an autosomal dominant disorder that occurs due to mutations of genes encoding desmosomal junctional proteins. It typically manifests as right-sided heart failure and can cause sudden cardiac death. Histology shows loss of myocytes, fatty infiltration, and focal fibrosis.

Option D: HCM occurs due to mutations in the gene encoding α-tropomyosin. However, this is rare, and HCM occurs most commonly due to mutations in genes encoding myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7).

Related Pearl: One-liners on Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Missense mutation
  • Most common mutation: Beta-chain of myosin
  • Myofibre disarray on histology
  • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy
  • Diastolic dysfunction
  • Systolic function normal
  • On Echocardiography:
    1. Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm
    2. Systolic anterior motion of left leaflet
    3. Banana shaped left ventricle

questions.text: A middle aged man presents with complaints of shortness of breath, chest pain and cough. The following catheter is being used to evaluate the patient for pulmonary hypertension. Identify the catheter.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-Ganz catheter used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter and is used to diagnose and evaluate pulmonary artery hypertension.

The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. It contains 4 internal lumens. The distal port is used to measure PAP (pulmonary artery pressure) while the 2nd port is used to measure CVP (central venous pressure).

Pulmonary artery catheterization is a diagnostic procedure in which a catheter is passed through the central vein, into the right atrium and the right ventricle, and then is finally placed in the pulmonary artery.

The indications include:

  • Evaluation of pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Measurement of pressures in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery
  • Assessment of etiology and volume status in shock
  • Assessment of congenital heart disease, cardiac shunts, and right-sided valvular disease

Complications :

  • Catheterization related:
    1. Arrhythmias, ventricular fibrillation
    2. Right bundle branch block, complete heart block
  • Catheter residence related:
    1. Mechanical, catheter knots
    2. Thromboembolism
    3. Pulmonary infarction
    4. Infection, endocarditis
    5. Endocardial damage, cardiac valve injury
    6. Pulmonary artery rupture
    7. Pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm
  • Others:
    1. Misinterpretation of data
    2. Misuse of equipment

Other options:

All the other catheters mentioned are used for establishing a central venous line for long-term total parenteral nutrition, medications, etc.

The given image shows a triple lumen catheter (option B):

 

The given image shows a peripherally inserted central catheter (Option C). It can be inserted via peripheral veins in pediatric patients.

 

The given image shows double lumen catheter (Option D).

questions.text: In a 62-year-old male posted for prostatectomy, the urologist decides to take the approach indicated by 2 in the image given below. This is the
questions.solution:
The approach that is marked with 2 is retropubic or the Millin approach.

 In this approach, using a low, curved transverse suprapubic Pfannenstiel incision, the recti are split in the midline and retracted to expose the bladder. With the patient in the Trendelenburg position, the surgeon separates the bladder and the prostate from the posterior aspect of the pubis. In this approach the exposure of the inside of the prostatic cavity is good. However, this procedure is rarely performed nowadays as it has been largely superceded by HOLEP - Holmium laser enucleation of the prostate. In situations where HOLEP is not available or where diverticulectomy or the removal of large stones are required, this open operation may be performed. 

Other option in the image:

1-Transurethral approach (TURP) is the most commonly used approach

2- Retropubic approach is called the Millin approach.

3- Transvesical approach, also known as Freyer approach. 

4- Perineal approach is also called the Young operation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. Identify the sign and the type of twin gestation it indicates.
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

The "T sign" seen in sonographic images signifies a monochorionic twin pregnancy, where there is a lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female patient complains of nipple discharge for the past 3 months. On examination, green-colored discharge is found oozing from the right nipple and no underlying lump was palpable. Imaging of the breast shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of green-colored nipple discharge along with the coarse rod and branching calcifications that give a 'broken needle' appearance in mammogram is suggestive of duct ectasia. 

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis, or even an abscess and fistula formation.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation, which involves the excision of all the major ducts.

Other options:

Option A- Fibroadenoma presents with a mobile breast lump and shows popcorn calcification on mammography.

 

Option C- Fat necrosis presents as a painless lump and can mimic a carcinoma which has to be ruled out by a biopsy. Fat necrosis shows lead pipe/ eggshell calcification.

 

Option D- Duct papilloma would present as a cystic swelling from a large lactiferous duct and is associated with blood stained discharge.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

From the surface:

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

From a single duct:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Intraductal papilloma (M/C cause)
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

From multiple ducts:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Carcinoma (M/C cause)
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green:
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent:
    • Infection
  • Serous:
    • Fibrocystic disease (M/C cause)
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: A middle-aged man underwent a routine health check-up. His lipid profile shows raised triglycerides. Identify the lipoprotein that transports dietary triglycerides to the liver.
questions.solution:
The lipoprotein that transports triglycerides from the intestine to the liver is the chylomicron. It is represented by 1 in the given image.

Chylomicron is the largest lipoprotein and has the most amount of triglycerides.

HDL has the least percentage of lipid content. HDL particles are the densest with a high protein to lipid ratio.

The density of various lipoproteins and their electrophoretic mobility are shown in the images below:

Related Pearl: Lipoprotein: Types, Sources and Action

Source

Action

Carry exogenous/dietary triacylglycerol from the intestine to peripheral organs

Very low density lipoproteins (VLDL)

Derived from the liver

Carry endogenous triacylglycerol from the liver to peripheral organs

Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)

Derived from VLDL

Involved in cholesterol transport

Derived from Liver, intestine, VLDL, chylomicrons

questions.text: A patient is undergoing endoscopic surgery for chronic sinusitis. Identify the site where enlargement of maxillary ostium is to be performed in the given diagram.
questions.solution:
In the given diagram, the maxillary ostium is marked as C. Enlargement of the maxillary ostium is performed during endoscopic surgery for sinusitis.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. The flow cytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes 3& 4) is shown below (Boxes 1 & 2 are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens, is unaffected, accounting for the presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.

The given clinical scenario and the flow cytometry is suggestive of Hyper IgM syndrome. The flow cytometry shows the following findings:

  • In comparison of image 3 to 1, where side scatter is plotted against CD 19: B-cell gating is present. 
    Gating of B cells means selecting a cell during a flow cytometry experiment for further analysis or data presentation.CD 19 is widely expressed on B cells. Hence the graph shows B cell gating. Side scatter measurement provides information about the granularity of a cell.
  • In comparison of image 4 to 2, where CD 40 is plotted against CD 19: B cells are present only in quadrant 4, which means that there is CD 40 deficiency.

The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens is unaffected, accounting for the presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.

Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results:

Interpretation of results:

Quadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen

Quadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens.

Quadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens 

Quadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen

 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with painful lesions in the nose and oral mucosa and enlarged lymph nodes. The microscopy of the patient's lymph node exudate shows the following appearance. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a man presenting with painful lesions in the nose and oral mucosa and microscopy of the lymph node aspirate showing pilot wheel appearance is characteristic of paracoccidioidomycosis which is caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

Paracoccidioidomycosis, also known as South Americal blastomycosis, is a chronic granulomatous infection typically involving the skin, mucosa, lymph nodes and internal organs.

The disease initially affects the lungs upon inhalation of the fungal spores and subsequently spreads by the hematogenous route to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics where it can cause ulcers and granulomas. These are characteristic clinical findings.

The causative agent is a thermally dimorphic fungus. In infected tissues, it is seen in yeast form with large oval cells surrounded by multiple buds encircling the mother cell. This is known as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance. The other form which exists is mycelium.

Microscopic examination of the sputum or other material from the lesions with potassium hydroxide (KOH) or calcofluor white stain helps demonstrate the presence of the fungus. Cultures on Sabouraud’s or yeast extract agar and serological examination are also helpful in the diagnosis.

Itraconazole is very effective against paracoccidioidomycosis, but ketoconazole and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can also be given. Severe disease is treated with amphotericin B.

The given image shows skin lesions in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis:

The given image shows swollen lymph nodes in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis.

The given image shows a CT scan of a patient with lung involvement in paracoccidioidomycosis. Note bilateral small nodules, ground-glass changes, and a cavitary lesion:

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: During your evening rounds in the ICU, you notice that the capnograph of a patient on controlled ventilation is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely cause that you would suspect?
questions.solution:
The given capnograph shows clefts in the plateau phase of expiration known as curare clefts. This indicates spontaneous breathing efforts by the patient.

The plateau phase of expiration in a capnograph represents the CO2 level in the air expired from the alveoli. During spontaneous breathing efforts, the patient might take inspiration which is not in sync with the controlled ventilation. This causes a decreased CO2 level which is seen as a dip/cleft in the capnograph.

This scenario might be seen when the patient is coming out of the effect of the neuromuscular blockade which is given to facilitate mechanical ventilation and to prevent patient-ventilator dys-synchrony.

Capnography is the quantitative method used to assess ventilation during the perioperative period. It provides a graphic representation of CO2 concentrations as a function of time or volume.

A normal time capnograph displays both inspiratory and expiratory phases, with the expiratory phase divided into three distinct components as shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient admitted to the intensive medical care unit with suspected meningoencephalitis is undergoing the procedure shown below. All the following structures are pierced during this procedure, except ________.
questions.solution:
The patient is undergoing a procedure of lumbar puncture as shown in the image. All the given structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, except the posterior longitudinal ligament.

Lumbar puncture is a diagnostic procedure done to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. The following structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, in that order:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura
  • Arachnoid
  • Subarachnoid space 

Indications:

  • Diagnosis of suspected meningitis and subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Spinal anesthesia and intrathecal administration of antibiotics/ chemotherapy
  • Therapeutic relief of pseudomotor cerebri, less frequently

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Absolute- Infection over the site 
  • Relative-
    • Coagulopathy
    • Raised intracranial pressure
    • Spinal epidural abscess

Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a common post-procedure symptom. It occurs due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. The headache in PDPH is typically frontal or occipital. It is aggravated with the upright or sitting posture and is relieved by lying supine. 

Other complications include infections, bleeding, cerebral herniation, and radicular pain.

The image given below shows the types of needles used for lumbar puncture.

The below image shows lumbar puncture being performed in the lying as well as the sitting position.

Related Pearl: Extent of important structures/spaces in the Spinal cord

  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

questions.text: A 15-month-old child is brought because of developmental delay and clouded appearance of the cornea in both eyes. The other examination findings of the child are shown in the image below. The elder sibling of the child also has similar findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows coarse facial features, umbilical hernia, claw hand, and thoracolumbar gibbus. These features along with corneal opacity and developmental delay are highly suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS).

The features mentioned in the above question are suggestive of MPS type 1. It is caused by the deficiency of α-l-iduronidase, leading to the storage of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The classical form of MPS 1 is known as Hurler syndrome, the intermediate form as Hurler–Scheie, and the most attenuated form is known as Scheie syndrome.

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are a group of genetic disorders (inborn errors of metabolism) affecting glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). They are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner and involve mutations of genes encoding lysosomal hydroxylases. Diagnosis is by demonstration of GAGs in urine or tissue biopsy samples, assays of suspected defective enzymes in white blood cells, fibroblasts, or serum, and testing for specific genes.

The given image shows cloudy cornea in mucopolysaccharidosis:

Other options -

Option B: Von Gierke’s disease or glycogen storage disease type 1a - Occurs due to the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, and affected children present with hepatosplenomegaly and fasting hypoglycemia.

Option C: Down's syndrome occurs due to trisomy 21. Affected children present with a flattened facial profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and epicanthic folds. Patients may be intellectually disabled.

Option D: Refsum disease - It is a disorder of fatty acid metabolism. It occurs due to deficiency of alpha-hydroxylase causing phytanic acid accumulation in the tissues. It presents with neurological symptoms, cerebellar ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, and polyneuropathy.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, headache, and cough with scanty sputum. His chest radiograph shows patchy consolidation of the left lower lobe. The culture of the sputum specimen shows the following appearance of colonies on Diene’s staining. What is the likely causative organism in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pneumonia along with the characteristic fried egg appearance of colonies on Diene’s staining is suggestive of Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Mycoplasma colonies can be best studied after staining with Diene's method. The colony is typically biphasic, with a fried egg appearance on PPLO agar. The central dark bluish area represents the area of mycoplasmal down growth whereas the pale blue periphery indicates superficial growth of mycoplasma on the agar.

Mycoplasma are the smallest free-living microorganisms and they can be grown in a cell-free medium. They lack a cell wall and are highly pleomorphic. They occur as granules and filaments of various sizes. They were previously called pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) since they were thought to cause pleuropneumonia in many animals and humans.

The species of mycoplasma causing human infections are:

  • M.pneumoniae causing pneumonia
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum causing non-gonococcal urethritis
  • M.hominis and M.gentalium causing genital tract infections

Pneumonia due to M. pneumonia is also referred to as Eaton agent pneumonia/ atypical pneumonia/ walking pneumonia. Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. Majority of patients with Mycoplasma pneumonia present with dry cough, sore throat, and fever.

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough

Dry cough
hemoptysis   scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an interstitial pattern of involvement.

 

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-
    • Overall- gram-negative bacilli (implicated as a group)
    • The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with Poland syndrome is set to undergo surgery for restoration of natural anatomical appearance. The given image illustrates a flap used as part of this process. Name the flap.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a muscle flap based on the thoracodorsal artery taken from Lattisimus dorsi.

 Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap

  • Either based on superior epigastric or inferior epigastric or both (supercharged TRAM)
  • Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest.
  • The rectus abdominis muscle is excised, and hence, the procedure leads to abdominal wall weakness (hernias can occur).

Latissimus dorsi flap:

  • Based on the thoracodorsal pedicle
  • It is an Axial flap

The image illustrates a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap.

In the below image, it is clearly seen that only skin and subcutaneous fat are moved. In contrast, the skin, fat, and muscle are moved in a TRAM flap.

Deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap

  • It is a free flap.
  • Only subcutaneous fat and skin is taken.
  • The rectus abdominis muscle is not removed, and hence, there is no abdominal wall weakness.
  • Cosmetically, it is the best flap, and it has the advantage of giving a "tummy tuck" to the patient as well.

questions.text: Kumar presented with massive proteinuria and peripheral oedema. Which among the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis, based on the slide obtained after renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
The slide shows a normal glomerulus which rules out the other diagnosis. Hence, the most likely diagnosis is minimal change disease as it has a normal appearance on light microscopy.

Minimal change disease shows effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy. This finding can also be seen in membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis shows focal and segmental sclerosis of glomeruli and hyalinosis of the capillary wall.

Option C: Membranous nephropathy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation (A) and irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane best seen with silver stains (B).

Option D: Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease or nodular glomerulosclerosis occurs in diabetics and shows ovoid or spherical PAS positive nodules with diffuse mesangial sclerosis and capillary basement membrane thickening.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with the following itchy lesions on the skin. It had appeared overnight and transformed into wheals and later into papules. The parents complain that he remains untidy and doesn't clean his room or bed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of itchy lesions on the trunk which transform into wheals and papules are likely due to bed bug bite.

Bed bugs (Cimex species) may infest beds and mattresses. They bite the exposed skin in touch with the bed and cause erythematous macules which may form classic 2-3 cm wheals in susceptible individuals. The bites are typically seen in clusters. Treatment involves giving antihistaminics to control itching. In case of infection, antibiotics may be recommended. To reduce bedbug infestations insecticides can be used over the infested items/spaces.

Other options

Chickenpox presents as a polymorphous rash with fever, The lesions occur in crops and represent different stages of healing.

Scabies occurs due to itch mite laying eggs in skin burrows. The itching is typically worse at night and distribution follows the circle of hebra. 

Miliaria or prickly heat occurs due to blockage of sweat gland ducts. As a result, the duct ruptures in the dermis. It presents as a papulovesicular rash.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient presents with complaints of vaginal discharge. Examination finding is shown below. Which of the following statements are false about this condition?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis infection presents with a pH of more than 4.5. The pathological finding shown in the image is colpitis macularis or “strawberry cervix,” which results from microscopic, punctate haemorrhages of the cervix. Trichomonas vaginalis is significantly associated with the clinical finding of colpitis macularis.

Trichomoniasis is the most common parasitic infection in humans in the industrialized world caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. Transmission is usually by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4–21 days.

Trichomoniasis characteristically causes a copious frothy yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. The discharge has an unpleasant odour.

In women, diagnosis is usually easily confirmed by examination of a wet film by phase contrast or dark‐field microscopy, but culture, usually in Feinberg–Whittington medium, gives the most reliable results. In men, examination of centrifuged urine or prostatic fluid following massage is only occasionally positive.

Standard treatment is with a single metronidazole 2 g oral dose. Regardless of treatment given, patients should avoid sexual contact for 7 days since the last antibiotic dose.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in colour) that indicate fatty tissue. This is suggestive of renal angiomyolipomas.

Angiomyolipomas (AMLs) are benign tumours that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. It is commonly seen in adults between 30 and 50 years of age, with a female predilection. AMLs predominantly affect the kidneys, though they can occur in other sites such as the liver (a common extra-renal location) and less frequently in the ovary, fallopian tube, spermatic cord, palate, and colon. 

Histologically, angiomyolipomas consist of perivascular epitheloid cells with varying proportions of vascular, immature smooth muscle cells, and fat cells. Patients with AMLs present with flank pain, a palpable mass, hematuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. Larger tumours increase the risk of complications, such as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, which can manifest as sudden-onset abdominal or flank pain, along with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and hypotension.

Everolimus is used for the treatment of angiomyolipomas. Treatment should be considered for asymptomatic, growing AMLs measuring >3 cm in diameter. Angiomyolipomas do not normally require surgery unless life-threatening bleeding is present.

Other options:

Renal cyst is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions need evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification is used for renal cysts. Cysts appear as hypodense lesions (greyish) with a thin wall, with or without septations.

CT image showing a simple renal cyst:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common malignant tumour of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It is a differential for angiomyolipoma but it is important to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who was treated with chemotherapy for a juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma of the optic chiasma presented with the following eye finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows Lisch nodules of the iris, which is a sign suggestive of von Recklinghausen disease or neurofibromatosis type 1. Astrocytomas frequently occur with neurofibromatosis type I.

Lisch nodules are hamartomas that appear as tiny nodular pigmented lesions which protrude above the surface of the iris.

Ocular manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 1:

  • Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma gives a characteristic S-shaped deformity of the upper lid. It is texturally reminiscent of a "bag of worms."
  • Optic nerve glioma, a pilocytic astrocytoma, typically occurs in young children.
  • Bilateral Lisch nodules
  • Congenital ectropion uveae
  • Prominent corneal nerves
  • Congenital glaucoma
  • Spheno-orbital encephalocele, due to dysplasia of the greater wing of the sphenoid

The ocular manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 2 are posterior subcapsular cataracts and hamartomas of the retinal pigment epithelium and retina.

Other options:

Option B- The ocular manifestations of Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome are retinal hemangiomas and optic nerve haemangiomas.

Option C- The ocular manifestations of tuberous sclerosis are atypical iris coloboma, iris hypopigmentation, and retinal astrocytoma.

Option D- The ocular manifestations of Sturge–Weber syndrome are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, ipsilateral glaucoma.

questions.text: A young girl comes to the opd with complaints of nodules on her hair shafts as seen in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows irregular white nodules along the hair shafts suggestive of white piedra.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:

  • White piedra: It is characterized by the presence of soft, white or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.
  • Black piedra: It is characterized by the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. It affects the scalp hair most often. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.

It is usually asymptomatic. Management involves cutting off the affected hair and usage of topical antifungals.

 

Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. It leads to alopecia and scarring of the affected area. The image below shows tinea capitis:

 

Tinea nigra is a localized fungal infection of the stratum corneum, especially affecting the palms. It produces brownish/blackish macular lesions. It is caused by Exophiala werneckii. The given image shows tinea nigra:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with resting tremors, slowness of movements, and a festinating gait. A clinical diagnosis of paralysis agitans was made. He, however, died later on due to other causes. At autopsy, a section of his brain was taken. What is true regarding the marked structure in this patient compared to that of normal individuals?

choices.text: Accumulation of synuclein and reduction in pigmentation
Accumulation of synuclein and increase in pigmentation
Accumulation of tau-proteins and reduction in pigmentation
Accumulation of tau-proteins  and increase in pigmentation

questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra with the accumulation of synuclein and reduction in pigmentation is seen in Parkinson's disease (paralysis agitans) compared to normal individuals.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Bradykinesia, rigidity and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Note: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease but is per se not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

Related Pearl: Synucleinopathies and tauopathies

Synucleinopathies:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
  • REM behavioral disorder
  • Pure autonomic failure 
Tauopathies:
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Down syndrome
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Corticobasal degeneration
  • Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia
  • Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica
  • Postencephalitic parkinsonism
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration
  • Niemann Pick disease type C
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

questions.text: A 41-year-old male patient who is diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma(RCC) undergoes nephrectomy. The histopathological image of the tumor is shown below. What is the subtype of RCC?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and histology specimen showing round or polygonal tumor cells with clear cytoplasm is suggestive of clear cell carcinoma. 

Clear cell carcinoma is the most common renal cell carcinoma. The growth pattern of clear cell carcinomas varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular. Cells are round or polygonal in shape. The cytoplasm is clear or granular and it contains glycogen and lipid.

Clear cell carcinoma mostly arises from the proximal tubular epithelium. It is associated with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3. The VHL gene (tumor suppressor gene) is located on chromosome 3p.

Clear cell carcinomas are usually single and unilateral. They are spherical masses that vary in size. Composed of yellow-colored tissue that distorts the renal outline. The yellow color is due to the accumulation of lipids in tumor cells.

The most common risk factors of renal cell carcinoma are tobacco usage, obesity, hypertension, and unopposed estrogen therapy. 

Other options:

Option B:  Papillary carcinoma arises from distal convoluted tubules. They can be multifocal and bilateral. The most common cytogenetic abnormalities associated are trisomies 7, 17 and loss of Y. Tumor cells are cuboidal or low columnar cells arranged in papillary formation with psammoma bodies as shown below.

Option C:  Chromophobe carcinoma arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. Tumor cells have pale eosinophilic cytoplasm with a halo around the nucleus and prominent cell membranes as shown below.

Option D: Collecting duct carcinoma is a rare type of renal cell carcinoma that arises from the collecting duct cells in the medulla. They show irregular channels lined by atypical epithelium with a hobnail pattern(Hobnail-shaped cells protruding into the glandular lumen marked by arrow) as shown below.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes
