questions.text: A farmer presented with a mass on his jaw, containing draining sinuses with purulent discharge. The culture of the discharge from the sinus grew colonies, which are shown in the image given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing molar tooth colonies that are characteristic of actinomyces species. The given clinical scenario describes a lumpy jaw seen in cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis is a chronic suppurative and granulomatous infection caused by Actinomyces. It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.

The image given below shows cervicofacial actinomycosis.

The image given below shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis is by examination of the pus from sinuses, sputum, or tissue specimens for sulfur granules. These granules are yellow, hard, lobulated, and made of tissue and bacterial filaments. Gram staining shows filamentous gram-positive bacteria.

Specimens should be cultured anaerobically on appropriate media such as chocolate blood agar, brain heart infusion broth, and brucella blood agar with hemin and vitamin K1. They may form molar-tooth colonies on agar and grows as clumps within the broth. Actinomyces species are mostly facultative anaerobes. 

Treatment is with IV penicillin for 2-6 weeks followed by oral therapy with penicillin or amoxicillin for serious infections.

Other options:

Option A: Cryptococcus usually manifests as meningitis with headache, neck stiffness, and disorientation. In addition, there may be lesions in the skin, lungs, or other organs. Cryptococcus produces whitish mucoid colonies. On microscopy, spherical budding yeast cells with a thick capsule are seen.

Option B: Bacillus anthracis usually manifests as cutaneous anthrax. The typical lesion has a characteristic central black eschar with marked edema. Microscopy shows gram-positive rods and culture on blood agar produce nonhemolytic gray to white, tenacious colonies with a ground-glass appearance. Comma-shaped outgrowths may project from the colony.

Option D: Klebsiella is a gram-negative, encapsulated, non-motile bacterium. It can cause pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and skin and wound infections. It produces a very viscous, mucoid growth when cultured on ordinary media. On MacConkey agar, they grow as lactose-forming colonies.

questions.text: The given image shows the synthesis and release of GABA at the nerve terminal. Identify the antiepileptic that mainly acts at site A.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as A is a GABA transporter. The drug that acts on GABA transporter is tiagabine. It inhibits the neuronal uptake of GABA and prolongs its time in the synaptic cleft, where the GABA molecules can activate GABA receptors.

Other drugs which act on the GABAergic pathway are:

  • Activation of GABA A receptors - Barbiturates, Phenobarbitone
  • Activation of GABA B receptors - Baclofen
  • Prevents the uptake of GABA - Tiagabine
  • Prevents the degradation of GABA (inhibits GABA transaminase) - Vigabatrin

Related Pearl: Important Adverse Effects of Anti-epileptic Drugs

Antiepileptic drugs

Adverse effects
Carbamazepine Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), diplopia, ataxia, hyponatremia
Phenytoin Gum hyperplasia, hirsutism, osteomalacia, ataxia
Valproic acid Hepatotoxicity, thrombocytopenia, transient alopecia, tremors, pancreatitis
Phenobarbital Sedation, depression, ataxia, automatism
Vigabatrin Loss of peripheral vision
Felbamate Fulminant hepatic failure, aplastic anemia
Lamotrigine Hypersensitivity reactions, SJS
Topiramate Paresthesias, renal calculi, weight loss, acute glaucoma
Oxcarbazepine Hyponatremia, SJS
Ezogabine Urinary retention
Zonisamide Renal calculi
Perampanel Homicidal ideation

questions.text: The following image shows the superior view of the first cervical vertebra. The part of the bone marked as number 7 gives attachment to ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Atlas bone. The part marked as number 7 is the posterior arch, and its inferior border gives attachment to ligamentum flavum.

 

Atlas (C1): Bony features include no body and spinous processes. It has 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets, anterior and posterior arches, and 2 transverse processes with lateral transverse foramen through which the vertebral vessels pass.

The anterior arch provides attachment to the anterior longitudinal ligament anteriorly and articulates with the facet of dens posteriorly.

The superior border of the posterior arch is attached to the atlantooccipital membrane and its inferior border is attached to the ligamentum flavum.

Articulation of the atlas:

  • The atlantooccipital joint allows the head to nod up and down (like showing yes).
  • The atlantoaxial joint allows the head to turn side to side (like showing no).

Axis (C2): Bony features include a cylindrical body, transverse process with transverse foramen, and a bifid spine. The dens (odontoid process) projects up to the space left due to the missing body of C1.

The given image shows the articulation of the atlas and the axis:

 

The stability of the vertebral column is maintained mainly by 4 ligaments - the anterior longitudinal, posterior longitudinal, ligamentum flavum, and the interspinous ligament.

C1 compression fracture at multiple sites is called Jefferson fracture. C2 hyperextension fracture is also called hangman fracture.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her otherwise healthy neonate with the lesion show in image. What would you do?

choices.text: Low dose broad spectrum antibiotic prophylaxis

questions.solution:
Reassure the mother that it is benign as the image shows Epstein Pearls.

Epstein Pearls

  • Are nests of epithelial cells.
  • Appear as whitish/yellowish spots on the hard palate.
  • It may also occur over the tip of Prepuce at 6 o'clock position.
  • Usually, resolve in 3 months.

 No intervention is necessary as it resolves spontaneously and is a benign condition.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A rural woman presents with her neonate having the condition shown in the image below. The neonate was healthy for the first 2-3 days after birth following which he developed progressive difficulty in taking feeds. She had a normal delivery but had not received any antenatal care. The possible cause is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a neonate with opisthotonus and progressive difficulty in taking feeds indicates lockjaw. The history indicates that the mother was not vaccinated during pregnancy. All these features are suggestive of neonatal tetanus.

Cerebral palsy is less likely as this condition does not show such rapid progression within days. Also, the lady had a normal delivery. CP is usually associated with hypoxia and injuries during birth, prematurity, and genetic abnormalities.

Neonatal meningitis and encephalitis may also lead to opisthotonus but do not correlate with progressive difficulty in taking feeds and unvaccinated status of the mother.

questions.text: A woman presented with the following lesion on her face. All are favorable prognostic factors in this condition except _________
questions.solution:
The absence of regression confers a favourable prognosis.

Regression is a phenomenon in which the host immune response, via tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, attacks the primary melanocytic tumor cells and leaves behind a fibrotic component. It describes an area where it appears there had been melanoma cells but these have been destroyed by the immune system and replaced with inflammatory cells or fibrosis. This phenomenon obliterates the tumor margin and increases the likelihood of incomplete excision. As a result, regression has been considered a poor prognostic factor in melanoma. The presence of regression could indicate metastasis.

Determinants of a more favorable prognosis in melanoma include:

  • thinner tumor depth
  • no or very few mitoses (< 1 per mm2)
  • a brisk tumor infiltrating lymphocyte response
  • the absence of regression
  • lack of ulceration
  • absence of metastases in the sentinel lymph node

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

  • Thickness (Breslow index)***
  • Sentinel node status***
  • Ulceration**
  • Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)
  • Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)
  • Age* (negative for older age)
  • Sex* (negative for males)
  • Location* (negative for head and neck)

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

questions.text: A 4 months-old male child was brought to the hospital with the complaints of a lesion in the abdomen as shown in the image. The drug used for the treatment of this condition is _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows flat to elevated, irregular, red-blue masses in the skin of the abdomen suggestive of hemangioma. Propranolol is the preferred treatment of infantile hemangioma complicated by ulceration or in symptomatic patients who require intervention.

It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis, and inhibition of angiogenesis. Propranolol at 2 mg/Kg/day has been found useful in infants younger than 6 months and children up to 5 years of age.

Complications of infantile hemangioma include pain, functional impairment, or permanent disfigurement.

Timolol is also used in the treatment of infantile hemangioma.

Options B, C, D: Bisoprolol, acebutolol, betaxolol are cardioselective beta-blockers that are not used in the treatment of hemangioma.

questions.text: A young person is brought to the hospital following a snake bite. The attendants have also brought the snake with them for identification. The image of the snake is given below. The poison of the snake is mainly:
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia is the first sign of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with a loss of appetite and increasing fatigue for the last few days. He has had multiple hospitalizations in the past but none of his records are currently available. On general examination, the following finding is found, amongst others. Which among the following would correlate best with this nail change?
questions.solution:
The nail change seen in the given image is leukonychia. It is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states such as renal failure.

Leukonychia is the opaque whitish discolouration of the nail. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency
  • Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine
  • Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiformae, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE
  • Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure
  • Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride)
  • Idiopathic

Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed - leukonychia striata or Aldrich–Mees lines.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

Nail finding

 Associated systemic condition

Clubbing
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Lung cancer
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • Complicated tuberculosis
  • Suppurative lung disease (lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis)
  • Mesothelioma
  • Cirrhosis
  • Congenital heart disease, Endocarditis

Koilonychia

Iron-deficiency anemia, hemochromatosis, Raynaud’s disease

Psoriasis, onychomycosis, hyperthyroidism, sarcoidosis, trauma, amyloidosis

Pitting

Psoriasis, Reiter’s syndrome, Alopecia areata

Beau’s lines

Any severe systemic illness that disrupts nail growth, Raynaud’s disease, pemphigus, trauma

Yellow nail

Lymphedema, pleural effusion, immunodeficiency, bronchiectasis, sinusitis, rheumatoid arthritis, nephrotic syndrome, thyroiditis, tuberculosis, Raynaud’s disease

Nail Pterygium

Dorsal: Lichen Planus

Ventral: trauma, systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, lupus erythematosus

 

Nail finding

Associated systemic condition

Muehrcke’s lines

Specific for hypoalbuminemia

questions.text: Mr. Raju, a 54-year-old male, complains of on and off difficulty in swallowing food. On performing an endoscopy the following finding is noted. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of a Schatzki’s ring in the lower end of the esophagus.

Schtazki’s ring is a circumferential ring present in the lower end of the esophagus near the squamocolumnar junction. The patients usually present with intermittent dysphagia during the hurried ingestion of solid foods.

Barium swallow and endoscopy will show the presence of a single ring in the distal portion of the esophagus.

Other options:

Eosinophilic esophagitis (option A) shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus.This appearance is called as the feline esophagus or ringed esophagus.

Esophageal web (option C) appears as a thin membrane. It can occur alone or as a part of Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Esophageal leiomyoma (option D) appears as an oval intramural mass arising from the wall of the esophagus.

questions.text: An otherwise asymptomatic 27-year-old female presents with complaints of mass in her oral cavity. It appears as below and feels bony hard on palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Torus Palatinus or Palatal tori are benign bone tumours of the maxilla that elevate the midline of the palate. They are sessile, spindle, or nodular in shape. They are neither neoplastic nor pathological and have slow and progressive growth. 

Palatal tori are benign maxillary bone tumors that are most often asymptomatic and do not require any specific management. However, surgical management may be necessary in case of prosthetic instability or pre-prosthetic surgery

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented to the clinic with pain and stiffness of the wrist with point tenderness over one of the carpal bones. Radiological workup was done and the X-ray showed increased opacity of one of the carpal bones suggesting avascular necrosis. He was subsequently diagnosed with Keinbock’s disease. Which of the labeled structures is involved?
questions.solution:
Keinbock’s disease involves the Lunate bone- the structure labelled as ‘B’ in the image above.

Keinbock’s disease or “traumatic softening” of the lunate bone  is a form of ischaemic necrosis, probably due to chronic stress or injury, It has been suggested that relative shortening of the ulna (‘negative ulnar variance’) predisposes to stress overload of the lunate between the distal edge of the radius and the carpus, but this has not been proven convincingly.

As in other forms of ischaemic necrosis, the pathological changes proceed in four stages:

Stage 1 – ischaemia without naked-eye or radiographic abnormality

Stage 2 - trabecular necrosis with reactive new bone formation and increased radiographic density, but little or no distortion of shape

Stage 3 - Collapse of the bone

Stage 4 - Disruption of radio-carpal congruence and secondary osteoarthritis.

Diagnosis:

MRI is the most reliable way of detecting the early changes.

A gadolinium-enhanced MRI scan will demonstrate the condition even if plain x-rays are normal.

Stage X-ray, MRI Treatment
1 Normal x-ray, changes on MRI

Cast for 3 months

Vascularized bone graft
2 Lunate sclerosis on plain x-ray, fracture lines sometimes present

Vascularized bone graft.

If negative ulnar variance: radial shortening

If positive ulnar variance: radial dome osteotomy
3a Fragmentation of lunate; height preserved Proximal row carpectomy
3b Collapse of lunate, proximal migration of capitate, fixed scaphoid rotation

Scapho-capitate fusion

Scapho-trapezium-trapezoid fusion

Proximal row carpectomy
4 Midcarpal or radio-carpal arthritis

Proximal row carpectomy

Total wrist fusion

Wrist replacement    

Related Pearl: Osteochondritis

Osteochondritis Bones affected
Kienbock Lunate
Scheuermann Ring epiphysis of the vertebra
Perthes Proximal femoral epiphysis  
Osgood-Schlatter Tibial tuberosity
Sever Calcaneum
Kohler Navicular bone
Freiberg

Second

(or 3rd,4th,5th)metatarsal head 
Iselin  Fifth metatarsal base

questions.text: An elderly woman presents to the clinic with a history of a tingling sensation of hands and feet for the past 3 months. She has no history of diabetes. On examination, the following finding was observed on her hands. Which of the following is least likely to be inhibited in this case of poisoning?
questions.solution:
The image shows mottled pigmentation on the hands of the patient (raindrop pigmentation) suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. Heme synthesis is not inhibited by arsenic.

The mechanism of action of arsenic poisoning involves the interaction of the trivalent form of arsenic (arsenite) with the sulfhydryl group (-SH) of lipoic acid forming a stable complex and causing inhibition of reactions requiring lipoic acid as a cofactor. Examples:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (or pyruvate oxidase)
  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase

In another mechanism, the pentavalent form of arsenic (arsenate) competes with inorganic phosphate and inhibits the steps requiring the production of ATP or NADH using Pi. Examples:

  • Glycolysis (inhibition of the conversion of G3P to 1,3 BPG by interacting with Pi).
  • Oxidative phosphorylation (Inhibition of ATP production by interacting with Pi).

Note:

Lead interacts with sulphydryl groups of cysteine in proteins and interferes with the action of the enzyme ferrochelatase required for heme synthesis.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented to the outpatient department with complaints of increased vaginal discharge. This was not associated with any itching. The discharge has a characteristic odour that gets accentuated on adding KOH and the workup of vaginal discharge revealed the following findings on pH analysis and microscopic examination of a saline mount. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the alkaline pH of vaginal discharge (pH test ~ 8 ) and presence of Clue cells on microscopy points towards a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Clue cells are epithelial cells with the surfaces covered by adherent bacilli seen in stained or unstained films.

Bacterial Vaginosis is characterized by malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge. Gardnerella Vaginalis is the causative organism among others such as Mycoplasma hominis, prevotella, ureaplasma, and peptostreptococcus. 

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria and Nugent's score

Amsel's Criteria: (any 3 should be present)

  • Thin, white/yellow homogenous vaginal discharge
  • pH of Vaginal fluid  >4.5
  • Fishy odor accentuated on adding 10% KOH
  • Clue cells on microscopy

Nugent's score is used to count the number of Gardnerella vaginalis, mobilincus, and lactobacillus in the gram-stained smear or vaginal discharge. A score of ≥7 is diagnostic

Treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg BD for 7 days.

Other options

Leucorrhea is a normal vaginal discharge that is acidic due to the metabolism of glycogen by the lactobacillus. Discharge in such a case appears nonpurulent when examined under the microscope

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions as shown below. He admitted to chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a brownish moiré pattern that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coli.

Bisacodyl is also implicated in causing melanosis coli.

questions.text: A young man presented with a single painless ulcer on the genitalia without any lymph nodes enlargement. Microscopic examination of a smear from the lesion showed the following finding. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The causative organism is Klebsiella granulomatis. The image shows Donovan bodies in a WBC showing closed-safety pin appearance. This finding along with the clinical presentation is suggestive of granuloma inguinale/ donovanosis.

Granuloma inguinale, or donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted chronic inflammatory disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a minute, encapsulated, Coccobacillus.

The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.

 Four types of lesions have been described in this condition:

  • Ulcerogranulomatous - most common type with painless beefy red ulcers. They are also highly vascular and bleed on touch.
  • Hypertrophic - usually with a raised irregular edge
  • Necrotic - offensive smelling ulcer that causes tissue destruction
  • Sclerotic or cicatricial - with fibrous or scar tissue

Primary lesions can occur on genital and extragenital sites. Lesions are not usually accompanied by lymphadenopathy, but subcutaneous extension of granulo­mas may mimic enlarged lymph nodes (called pseudobuboes). 

The diagnosis is usually made by microscopic presence of Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces inside large mononuclear cells. They show bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a closed safety-pin appearance.

Treatment consists of prolonged antibiotic therapy, for a period of 6 weeks with oral azithromycin (1st line), or oral doxycycline (2nd line).

The given image shows Intracellular Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears:

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed an injury to the ligaments commonly referred to as the 'unhappy triad'. Which of the following ligaments are involved?

choices.text: Posterior cruciate ligament and lateral meniscus
Anterior cruciate ligament and medial meniscus
Anterior and posterior horns of lateral meniscus

questions.solution:
The unhappy triad of the knee involves:

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man admitted to ICU develops sepsis 3 days after insertion of a central venous catheter. A peripheral blood smear reveals the following. What does the structure marked by the arrow indicate?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body.

Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders are:

  • Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules
  • Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles
  • Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles 

The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented to the emergency department after a fall with complaints of left wrist pain. On physical examination, the patient was found to have swelling and tenderness at his left thumb base. He denied any paresthesias, tingling, or numbness. His X-Ray is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Rolando's fracture. It is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration with 3 major segments—the metacarpal shaft, the volar fragment, and the dorsal fragment.

Mechanism of injury of the Rolando fracture is an axial load crushing the articular surface. The patient often presents with a swollen and tender thumb base.

The fracture can be managed with closed reduction and k wiring or by open reduction and plate fixation.

Other options-

Bennet’s fracture is defined as an intra-articular two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone which may occur due to forced abduction of the first metacarpal.

While both Bennett’s and Rolando's fractures are intra-articular fractures of the metacarpal base, the differentiating feature is that Rolando’s fracture is a comminuted fracture whereas Bennett’s fracture has a single fracture line.

Barton’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Boxer’s fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: An 81-year-old lady presented with the following raised lesion which has gotten itchy. It is scaly but does not produce bleeding on itching. A short course of steroids is given but no improvement is seen. Biopsy revealed full-thickness epidermal dysplasia with loss of epithelial polarity. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and biopsy findings suggest a likely diagnosis of Bowen's disease

Bowen’s disease is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma. It is characterized by a persistent, solitary,  non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy.

It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It is commonly seen in patients more than 60 years of age and predominantly seen in women. Human Papilloma Virus 16 infection is associated with it.

It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.  Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia with loss of polarity.

Initially, patients present with a small, red, and slightly scaly area, which gradually enlarges in an irregular fashion. The margins of the lesions are slightly raised with the surface is usually flat. Bowen disease on perianal skin carries a higher risk of invasion and recurrence. Management includes cryotherapy, curettage, topical 5% 5-fluorouracil, 5% imiquimod cream. 

Other options:

Option A- Plaque psoriasis is the most common clinical type of psoriasis. Psoriatic plaques are symmetrical, well defined, and erythematous distributed over the elbow, knees, and lower back. On removal of the slivery-white scales, it shows pinpoint bleeding spots called the Auspitz sign. Histology shows parakeratosis, spongiform pustules, microabscesses with the neutrophil collection, and tortuous dilated papillary capillaries.

Option B- Discoid dermatitis has large multiple plaques and mainly presents with pruritus. Histology shows parakeratosis, intracellular edema, eosinophils, and exocytosis of lymphocytes. Most of the cases show improvement with corticosteroids. 

Option D- Malignant melanoma is the malignant transformation of melanocytes that are derived from neural crest cells. it is commonly found in patients younger than 55 years. The characteristics of melanoma are:

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variations, especially red, white, and blue tones in a brown or black lesion
  • Diameter greater than 6 mm
  • Evolution

Histopathology shows individual melanoma cells which are larger than normal melanocytes. They have large nuclei with irregular contours, chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red eosinophilic nucleoli.

questions.text: The insulin regimen of a diabetic patient is demonstrated in the image below. The X axis represents time of the day and the y axis represents the effect of insulin. The arrows indicate the time of administration of insulin. Identify the insulin preparations marked A, B and C respectively.
questions.solution:
In the given image, A represents glulisine, B represents regular insulin and C represents NPH.

In the insulin regimen elaborated above,

  • Insulin preparation A has duration of action between breakfast and lunch - 3-4 hours . This indicates it is a ultra short acting insulin preparation - aspart, glulisine or lispro.
  • Insulin preparation B has a duration of action slightly longer than preparation A indicating it is a short acting insulin preparation - regular insulin
  • Insulin preparation C is administered twice in a 24-hour period indicating it is an intermediate acting preparation - NPH or lente.

Glargine, detemir and degludec are long acting insulin preparations mostly having once daily administration.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with hair loss. The hair loss is patchy as shown in the image below. Black dots are noted in areas of hair loss. Which of the following types of tinea is this child suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicting a young child with patchy hair loss and the image showing black dots is suggestive of endothrix type of tinea capitis.

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children. Clinical features of tinea capitis are patchy hair loss, scaling, tender lymphadenopathy, and in severe cases, there might be pustules and crusting of the affected area along with sinus formation. 

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Endothrix - a non-inflammatory type in which multiple black dots are present within the areas of alopecia. It is most commonly caused by T. tonsurans and T. violaceum.
  • Ectothrix -a mild inflammatory type in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen. Microsporum audouinii, M.canis, M.equinnum, and M.ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.
  • Kerion -a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation. It is commonly caused by T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Favus - is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. It is caused by T. schoenleinii

Treatment:

  • Terbinafine: <10 Kg- 62.5 mg; 10-20 kg - 125 mg; >20 kg- 250 mg, all given daily for 4 weeks.
  • Itraconazole: 2-4 mg/kg/day for 4-6 weeks.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, and diarrhea. Several investigations were done, including an intestinal biopsy, which appears as shown below. Which among the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows a non-caseating granuloma. Among the given options, Crohn’s disease is the most likely condition in the given case.

Non-caseating granulomas can be seen in

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Berylliosis
  • Crohn's disease

Granulomas are generally not seen in ulcerative colitis and irritable bowel syndrome. Tuberculous granuloma is an example of caseating granuloma, which has central necrosis with amorphous granular debris and a cheese-like macroscopic appearance. The given image does not show a necrotic center, making it unlikely to be tuberculosis.

The image below shows a tuberculous granuloma with a necrotic center.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions are also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease:

It is a mild exanthematous fever that usually occurs in children, but may also occur in adults. It is characterized by papulovesicular rashes that involve the oral mucosa, palms, and soles.

The virus is shed in the stool and is transmitted by the feco-oral route. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously.

Coxsackieviruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types, and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses include -

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) 
  • Herpangina - It is febrile vesicular pharyngitis. It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, palate, or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Aseptic meningitis

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses include -

  • Pleurodynia or Bornholm disease- It is viral myalgia defined by sudden severe lancinating pain, typically on one side of the chest. It is commonly associated with fever, malaise, and headaches. 
  • Myocarditis and pericarditis in the newborn.
  • Orchitis, juvenile diabetes

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet: 

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus causes impetigo. It is characterized by sores around the mouth and the nose and typically forms a honey-colored scab. It is more commonly seen in children. It is not associated with lesions on palms and soles.

The image given below shows impetigo.

Option C: Human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) is a T-lymphotropic human herpes virus transmitted via saliva. It may cause roseola infantum/ sixth disease/ exanthem subitum in infants and young children. Roseola infantum is primarily caused by HHV-6.

The image given below shows typical rashes in an infant with exanthem subitum.

Option D: Poxvirus causes molluscum contagiosum in children and young adults. It is characterized by pink or pearly white wart-like nodules with central umbilication on the skin. 

The image given below shows molluscum contagiosum lesions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female from tribal area presented with fever for the last 3 days. On examination of the peripheral smear, a diagnosis of malaria was made. Which of the following is most likely to be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

questions.text: A middle-aged man has been recently diagnosed with hypertension. He wants to try lifestyle changes before starting with pharmacological therapy. According to the rule of halves, where is he represented in the diagram, if A represents the whole population?
questions.solution:
According to the rule of halves, the person is represented in category C which represents people diagnosed with hypertension but not treated. This is because the patient has not yet started lifestyle management or pharmacotherapy.

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. The rule depicts the disease burden of hypertension in the community.

It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

Pictorial representation of the rule of halves in hypertension is shown below:

Hypertension can be prevented by primary and secondary prevention strategies. Primary prevention includes non-pharmacological measures such as lifestyle changes that are taken to reduce the incidence of the disease. It includes:

  • Population strategy approach aimed to reduce the incidence of the disease at the whole population level
  • High-risk strategy approach is done to identify high-risk individuals 

Secondary prevention includes pharmacological measures such as the usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. It aims at early detection, adequate treatment, and follow-up of the patients to ensure proper compliance.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous or fistula and it's connections. 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities: Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between the yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated. The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct leads to various abnormalities depending on which part of the duct remains patent.

  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near the umbilicus leads to the umbilical polyp or sinus.
  • Persistence of the distal end with mucus retention leads to the cyst, which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by a fibrous band.
  • A fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to an enterocutaneous fistula.

Patent urachus occurs due to the failure of urachus to obliterate, resulting in a connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.

Urachal cyst occurs when the urachus fails to obliterate but there is no connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.

The given image below shows a urachal cyst (UC) attached to Meckel’s diverticulum (MD) on one side and urinary bladder (UB) on the other side with a patent tract- urachus (U).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with an increasing number of tense, fluid-filled blisters on the inner arms and legs. Histopathology revealed a subepidermal blister rich in eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence shows a pattern as in the image given below. Antibodies against which of the following antigens is implicated in this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with a subepidermal blister rich in eosinophils and direct immunofluorescence showing a linear pattern is suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. Antibodies against hemidesmosome are implicated in this disease.

Other options:

  • Antibodies against desmoglein are seen in pemphigus vulgaris (Dsg-3) and pemphigus foliaceous (Dsg 1). They are an intraepithelial blister that show a fishnet pattern under direct immunofluorescence.
  • Antibodies against epidermal transglutaminase are seen in dermatitis herpetiformis. They consist of subepidermal blisters with neutrophils in dermal papillae.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman who had a long history of dyspnoea, chronic cough, and wheezing passed away due to respiratory failure following pneumonia. She was a smoker. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a gross specimen of lung with panacinar emphysema. The clinical scenario and image is associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the entire acinus is enlarged from the level of respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.

α1-antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes.

Other options- 

Option A: Absent dynein arm causes primary ciliary dyskinesia. 

Option B: Mutation in the CFTR gene causes cystic fibrosis. Both the above conditions lead to bronchiectasis.

Option D: Antibodies against type 4 collagen cause Goodpasture syndrome which leads to pulmonary hemorrhage and nephritis.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: A 24-year-old male started going to the gym as a part of his new year's resolution. He started exercising without warm-up and started having thigh pain after sudden jerky flexions of the knee. MRI was done to reveal the tear of the hamstring muscle with the following origin and insertions. Select the affected muscle.
questions.solution:
The given description of a hamstring muscle with origin on ischial tuberosity and insertion on fibula is the Biceps femoris. 

  • Hamstrings are muscles of the back of the thigh that act as a flexor of the knee and extensors of the hip.
  • While Biceps cause lateral rotation of the leg, semimembranosus, and semitendinosus cause medial rotation.
  • They take origin from the ischial tuberosity and are attached to one of the bones of the leg.
  • All are innervated by the tibial part of the Sciatic nerve.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of continuous diarrhoea that started 20 hours ago. He is drowsy and unresponsive. His eyes are sunken and skin turgor is poor. The appearance of his stool is given below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic rice watery stools which is due to Vibrio cholerae. 

Cholera exotoxin activates adenylate cyclase (↑ cAMP) leading to loss of bicarbonate, water, and electrolytes.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes with complaints of fatigue and weight loss. An image of her thyroid scan is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the thyroid scan showing a diffusely increased uptake of radioactive iodine and an enlarged size of the gland is suggestive of Grave’s disease.

A thyroid scan helps to differentiate between a hot nodule and a cold nodule. Thyroid nodules that absorb radioiodine are called hot nodules. These nodules produce excess thyroid hormones. Whereas, the thyroid nodules that do not absorb radioiodine are called cold nodules and they indicate non-functional nodules.

Appearance of thyroid scan in other thyroid disorders:

Multinodular goiter demonstrates multiple areas of both increased and decreased uptake of radioiodine, indicating the presence of both functioning and nonfunctioning nodules.

Toxic adenoma demonstrates a focal area of increased uptake of radioiodine.

Thyroiditis shows a decreased uptake of radioiodine due to follicle damage.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the marked foramen?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the jugular foramen. The glossopharyngeal nerve passes through it.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus

questions.text: Mr. Rajesh comes with complaints of double vision that gets worse after he reads a book or watches television. He also has drooping of the eyelids that gets better after a nap. Serology is positive for anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. A CT scan of his chest is given below. What is seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms with positive anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies suggest a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis and the CT image shows an anterior mediastinal mass suggestive of thymoma. 

Myasthenia gravis is associated with the development of thymoma. The muscle-like cells within the thymus called myoid cells, express AChRs on their surface. These cells can serve as a source of autoantigen and trigger autoimmune reactions within the thymus gland.

questions.text: A patient develops a sore throat after general anaesthesia. He was diagnosed as having a postoperative sore throat (POST). The anaesthetist injects a local anaesthetic in the plane of the marked structure. Which of the following pierces the marked structure?

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve, accompanied by inferior thyroid vessels
External laryngeal nerve, accompanied by inferior thyroid vessels
Internal laryngeal nerve, accompanied by superior laryngeal vessels
External laryngeal nerve, accompanied by superior laryngeal vessels

questions.solution:
The marked structure shows the thyrohyoid membrane. It is pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve, along with superior laryngeal vessels. USG-guided block of the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is used in the management of POST. 

The diagram given below shows the structures piercing the thyrohyoid membrane.

The thyrohyoid membrane is a fibroblastic layer connecting the superior border of the thyroid cartilage to the superior border of the body and the greater cornu of the hyoid.

It facilitates the ascent of the larynx during swallowing.

It is pierced by superior laryngeal vessels and the internal laryngeal nerve. It, therefore, serves as the potential target for ultrasound-guided local anaesthetic injection if an internal laryngeal block is needed to alleviate POST.

questions.text: A 30-year-old apparently healthy man developed abdominal pain at the airport. An x-ray was obtained, which is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple cylindrical capsules in the stomach and intestine, which are consistent with a diagnosis of body packer syndrome.

Body packers are individuals who swallow illegal drugs like heroin and cocaine with the purpose of smuggling. Usually, the drugs are carefully wrapped in latex or plastic and swallowed, to be excreted later with the help of laxatives.

Drugs are usually of similar radio-opacity as fecal material and may be difficult to detect on x-rays. CT scan may be done to aid in diagnosis.

The image below shows multiple cylindrical capsules in the stomach and intestine. 

A similar term is body stuffer syndrome, which refers to consumption or stuffing drugs in the rectum or vagina just when the person is apprehensive of being caught. Drug toxicity may be seen due to systemic absorption.

Other options:

Option A-  Bezoar formation is an indigestible mass due to the consumption of a variety of materials that were intentionally or accidentally ingested indigestible substances.

The image below shows a colonic bezoar due to the ingestion of box myrtle seeds.

Option B- Pica is eating non-nutritive, non-food substances like chalk, paper, ash, and mud over a period of at least one month in patients with iron-deficiency anemia.

Option D- Appendicolith is the accumulation of firm feces with mineral deposits. These deposits are seen incidentally in abdominal computed tomography without any signs of appendicitis. It may obstruct the appendix lumen, causing appendicitis, and is rarely found in patients with appendix inflammation.

The image below shows a CT of an appendicolith.

questions.text: The image shows a male child with an anterior abdominal wall that is flabby and thin.   The bowel contours appear obvious on inspection and on examination the scrotum is empty. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Prune Belly Syndrome.

Prune Belly Syndrome is also known as - Eagle Barrett Syndrome, Triad Syndrome, Obrinsky Syndrome, Frohlich Syndrome.

Prune Belly Triad -

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, Hypotonic & Thin Abdominal Wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism.
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye. On fundus examination, the following finding was seen. Which among the following conditions is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows a splashed sauce appearance which is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). 

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden loss of vision. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is present.

Funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

Complications:

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100 day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of CRVO.

Other options:

Option A- The funduscopy findings in central retinal artery occlusion include pale retina, thread-like arteries, a cherry-red spot in the macula, and cattle trucking (segmentation of blood in the retinal veins). It is shown below.

Option C: The funduscopy in retinal detachment shows detachment of fovea and macula, as shown below.

Option D: Fundoscopy changes in retinitis pigmentosa include perivascular retinal hyperpigmentation, narrow retinal arterioles, atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium, and disc pallor. It is shown below.

questions.text: The skeletal remains of a person were brought to a forensic lab. The following gunshot wounds were found on his skull. Which of the following is true about these wounds?

choices.text: A and B both are entry wounds

questions.solution:
In the given image, A is the entry wound as it has a clean punched-in appearance on the outer table of the skull. Whereas B is the exit wound as it shows beveling (sloping surface) on the outer table of the skull.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

  • Bevelling: inner table
  • Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, the same pattern occurs, this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

  • Bevelling: outer table
  • Punched out hole: inner table

Krönlein shot is a rare injury of the skull caused by a close-range shot. Here, the cranium is blasted open and large pieces of brain matter are ejected out of the skull.

Related Pearl: Difference between Wound of Entry and Exit

questions.text: A young man presents with painful genital lesions shown below to a Suraksha clinic. He has no other complaints like burning micturition, discharge, or inguinal swelling. Which colored kit should be used for his management?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a close cluster of cutaneous blisters on the penile shaft. This indicates genital herpes. The red kit is used for genital herpes.

Genital herpes is caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2) pathogen. It begins as blisters, on or around the genitals or rectum. These blisters break causing ulcers.

Though other causes of genital ulcers might present with blisters, only the red kit is used for genital vesicles among the options given. He does not have complaints which require the other kits mentioned.

Other options: 

  • Grey kit- for urethral discharge
  • Black kit- for inguinal bubos
  • Green kit- for vaginal discharge

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A 40-year-man presents with hematuria, polyuria, and hypertension. The resected kidney is as seen below. All are associated with this condition except ______.

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen
Portal fibrosis and proliferation of portal bile ducts

questions.solution:
Clinical history and gross image suggest that the patient has autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). They are associated with cysts in liver, spleen, and pancreas; berry aneurysms; and mitral valve prolapse.

Note: 

Patients with autosomal-recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD

  • Autosomal-dominant disorder
  • Multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure
  • 40% have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease)
  • Cysts in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms arise in the circle of Willis à subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1 and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2
  • Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: A 5-day-old infant is seen with transient rashes as shown in the image.  On microscopic examination, papular lesions on an erythematous base with eosinophil laden sterile lesions are seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erythema toxicum is the most probable diagnosis. This condition presents with papular lesions on an erythematous base with eosinophil laden sterile lesions, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. It is a normal finding in many newborns. They are seen 1–3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week and resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment

Other options:

Option B: Pustular melanosis is a benign transient condition that lasts for 2-3 days in newborns. It is seen predominantly in black neonates. The lesions are vesiculopustular eruption and have neutrophils.

Option C: Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

Option D: Milia are small cysts formed around the pilosebaceous follicles usually seen over nose, cheek, forehead. Pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. Resolve spontaneously without scarring.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: In a patient, a recording of jugulovenous pressure was assessed by the resident and he tried correlating it with the patient's heart sounds. Which of the following heart sound occur just after this pressure waveform marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The heart sound occurring just after the pressure waveform marked by the arrow is S1. The waveform marked in the image is 'a wave' and it corresponds to atrial contraction.

S1 (first heart sound) is heard in the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle where ventricles contract against closed mitral valves. This occurs after atrial systole, corresponding to 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure. Thus, S1 can be heard just after the 'a' wave. 

Jugular venous pressure measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with the superior vena cava and right atrium. 

 

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

The Wiggers diagram given below correlates JVP with other aspects of the cardiac cycle. 

Other options - 

Option A: S4 is heard in the phase of atrial systole where atria contract in the late stage of ventricular filling. This occurs just before S1 and 'a' wave in the JVP. 

Option B: S3 is heard in the passive ventricular filling phase where mitral valves are open. It is seen after the 'v' wave peak in the JVP. 

Option D: S2 is heard due to the closure of aortic and pulmonary valves in the isovolumetric relaxation phase after ventricular systole. It can be heard just before the 'v' wave corresponding to the JVP waveform. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

Related Pearl: Heart sounds
