questions.text: A middle-aged woman diagnosed with depression presented to your OPD for a follow-up. You notice a characteristic sign marked by an arrow in the image. Identify this sign.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the arrow indicates Veraguth's sign or Veraguth's fold, a diagonal palpebral fold running from the lateral corners of the eyes, medially upward to the medial end of the eyebrows. It is a physical sign of depression.

Another physical sign of depression is the Omega sign. In this, there is vertical wrinkling between the eyebrows joined at the top by a horizontal crease.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presented with complaints of blurring of vision. The patient's fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a diabetic patient with the blurring of vision and an FFA image showing a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). It occurs due to the accumulation of dye in the macular region.

CME is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression. In advanced cases, a lamellar macular hole may develop. Treatment includes topical anti-prostaglandins (ketorolac), steroids, systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (oral acetazolamide), and managing the causative factor. Given below is an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces in CME:

Other options:

Option A: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. Patients complain of sudden onset painless loss of vision, micropsia, and metamorphopsia. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stick pattern. OCT image of central serous retinopathy is seen below which neurosensory retinal detachment and accompanying small detachments of the retinal pigment epithelium.

Option B: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. Causes include trauma, CME, or idiopathic. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak. OCT image of the macular hole is seen below which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina.

Option D: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a bilateral disease affecting people who are above 50 years of age. It can be exudative or non-exudative types. There can be a gradual or sudden loss of vision depending on the type of AMD. Drusens (yellowish-white elevated spots caused by extracellular deposits in the macular region) of various types can be noted. FFA shows punctate hyperfluorescence due to the drusen. OCT and FFA image of drusens is shown below:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with the following swelling behind the ear. It was red and inflamed on examination. What should be done in this case now?

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the cyst
Surgical excision of the cyst content leaving behind a portion of the wall
Complete surgical excision including cyst wall

questions.solution:
The image provided shows a sebaceous cyst

A common site of a Sebaceous cyst is the postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule.

They are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum.

Treatment depends on the clinical state of the cyst. When inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially. Total surgical excision should be done once the inflammation has subsided. This is because the plane of dissection is not clearly visible in the inflamed state.

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called:
questions.solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia Cause
Airways Squamous metaplasia: Normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. 

Chronic smoking,

Deficiency of retinoic acid
Urinary bladder Squamous metaplasia: Normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. Bladder stones 
Esophagus Columnar metaplasia: Normal squamous epithelium is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus) Chronic GERD 
Cervix Squamous metaplasia: Normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium. Low pH of the cervix
Muscle Connective tissue metaplasia: Formation of bone in the muscle tissue; (myositis ossificans). After intramuscular hemorrhage

GERD: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

questions.text: Mr.Rajesh presents with complaints of hyperacusis after a surgical procedure. Which of the following nerves could be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The facial nerve, marked as 3 in the image could be responsible for hyperacusis.

The tensor tympani and the stapedius are the muscles of the middle ear and they are innervated by branches of V and VII cranial nerves respectively. Both these muscles contract in response to loud noises and thereby dampen the sound. The tensor tympani increases the tension of the tympanic membrane and reduces the force of vibration. Stapedius pulls the stapes posteriorly and reduces the oscillations.

Paralysis of the stapedius causes increased sensitivity to the sounds, a condition known as hyperacusis.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady with a known case of hypothyroidism presents with pain and burning of the lateral half of the palm. On examination, her palms appear as shown below and Phalen's test is positive. What is the likely structure under which the affected nerve is compressed?
questions.solution:
The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It is due to compression of the median nerve where it passes under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist.

Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the distribution of the median nerve. There may be a weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted.

Tinel's sign will be positive. This sign is elicited by percussing over the median nerve, reproducing symptoms. In Phalen's test,  the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion for 60 seconds.

Carpal tunnel syndrome can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

The following image shows Phalen's test.

Other options 

Option A- Ligament of Struthers connects the medial epicondyle and the humerus. It is associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve and produces similar symptoms as carpal tunnel syndrome. However, Phalen's test is negative.

Option B- Bicipital aponeurosis is the insertion of the biceps in the cubital fossa. It is also associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve. Phalen's test is negative.

Option C- Guyon's canal: The ulnar nerve can get compressed while passing through Guyon's canal. 

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes with complaints of poor vision in her right eye that has progressively worsened. She has had one episode of urinary incontinence in the past that self resolved. Examination reveals a visual deficit in her right eye. The MRI of her brain is given below. Identify the lesion in the MRI.
questions.solution:
The MRI shows Dawson’s fingers seen in multiple sclerosis. They are periventricular demyelinating plaques perpendicular to the body of lateral ventricles.

Other options:

Molar tooth sign is seen in Joubert syndrome. It is the elongated superior cerebellar peduncle giving the midbrain an appearance of a molar tooth in an axial section.

Tram track sign is the calcification of cortex seen in Sturge Weber syndrome.

Hummingbird sign, also known as the penguin sign is the appearance of the brainstem in progressive supranuclear palsy.

questions.text: A young boy presents with fever and pain while swallowing. He is also noticed to have a typical hot potato voice and drooling of saliva. The following finding is seen on oral examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing congested tonsil, pillar, and soft palate on the right side with a swollen and oedematous uvula pushed to the opposite side is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess or quinsy.

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. It is a complication of tonsillitis.

The clinical features include sore throat, dysphagia, odynophagia, hot potato voice, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever. On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

It is treated with intravenous antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscess. An interval tonsillectomy is done after 4-6 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Tonsillitis occurs due to bacterial infection of the faucial tonsils. Patients present with a sore throat, dysphagia, ear pain, and constitutional symptoms. Tonsils are enlarged and congested with/ without a membrane or yellowish spots over the tonsil.

The image below shows tonsillitis:

Option B: Adenoiditis refers to the infection of the nasopharyngeal tonsil that occurs due to repeated attacks of rhinitis, sinusitis, or tonsillitis in children. The patients present with nasal obstruction, and mouth breathing. The patients have characteristic adenoid facies i.e. elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, high arched hard palate, hitched up upper lip, prominent and crowded upper teeth. 

The images below show enlarged adenoids and adenoid facies respectively. 

Option D: Parotid abscess is the suppuration of the parotid space most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is seen in the postoperative period, dehydration, and debilitated patients. Patients appear toxic with swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness in the parotid gland and at the angle of the mandible. 

The image below shows a parotid abscess.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with pain in his knee for the past month. He is an avid basketball player. The pain increases during activity, but is not seen at rest. On examination, there is a swelling anterior and distal to the knee joint line. There is pain on extension against resistance. X-ray of the knee shows the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiographic image shows traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter disease.

Osgood-Schlatter disease refers to apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity that occurs due to persistent traction on the tibial tuberosity. The condition is associated with overuse and is often seen in those playing basketball and volleyball frequently. The common age group is 12-15 years in boys, while 9-13 years in girls. They present with pain and swelling over the tibial tubercle. 

Radiographic findings include

  • Widening of the physis between the apophysis and proximal tibia
  • The tibial tubercle apophysis is irregular
  • Apophysis gets fragmented

Other options:

Option A: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is a similar clinical condition to Osgood-Schlatter disease, but it affects the inferior portion of the patella. It is characterized by pain in the superior portion of the patellar tendon. Early radiographic findings are subtle or absent. Thickening of the proximal patellar tendon may be seen.

Option C: Hoffa’s disease is the impingement and inflammation of the infrapatellar fat pad. It is characterized by anterior knee pain. The radiographic image shows increased density in the infrapatellar pad of fat or Hoffa's fat pad.

Option D: Osteochondritis dissecans is a condition characterized by an area of subchondral bone that becomes necrotic and the cartilage overlying it undergoes degenerative changes. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies. On a radiograph, they appear as oval lucent areas adjacent to the articular margin. 

Related Pearl: Osteochondritis

Osteochondritis Bones affected
Kienbock Lunate
Scheuermann Ring epiphysis of the vertebra
Perthes Proximal femoral epiphysis  
Osgood-Schlatter Tibial tuberosity
Sever Calcaneum
Kohler Navicular bone
Freiberg

Second

(or 3rd,4th,5th)metatarsal head 
Iselin  Fifth metatarsal base

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl, who is yet to attain her menarche, presents with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performed and the histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?

AFP- Alpha-fetoprotein
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller-Duval bodies is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor/ endodermal sinus tumor.

Yolk sac tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. The tumors are solid masses that are yellow in color and hemorrhagic in nature. Schiller Duval bodies are pathognomonic findings that consist of a central capillary that is surrounded by tumor cells within a cystic area of the tumor. Alpha-fetoprotein is elevated. There is also the presence of intracellular and extracellular hyaline droplets. Clinical features typically include abdominal pain with a rapidly growing abdominal mass. 

Other options:

Option B: Dysgerminoma are the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. These tumor cells grow in sheets or cords and are infiltrated by lymphocytes. These cords are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. 

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. Numerous signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Signet ring cells are mucin producing cells with an appearance of signet ring often originating from the gastric mucosa.

 

Option D: Granulosa cell tumors arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. The image below shows the presence of Call- Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumor. These are glandlike small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A child is brought with the following deformity. This occurs due to the failure of fusion between the _____.

choices.text: Lateral nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Lateral nasal prominence and mandibular prominence
Medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Medial nasal prominence and mandibular prominence

questions.solution:
The image shows cleft lip (hare lip), which occurs due to the failure of fusion between the medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence.

Various defects of fusion of prominences in the face region are as follows:

Cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence.

Types:

  • Unilateral cleft lip - Failure of fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence on one side
  • Bilateral cleft lip - Failure of fusion of maxillary prominence with the medial nasal prominence on both sides
  • Median (midline) cleft lip - Failure of fusion of the two medial nasal prominences in the midline

Oblique facial cleft: Failure of fusion of the maxillary and lateral nasal prominence, giving rise to a gap running from the medial angle of the eye to the mouth. The nasolacrimal duct is not formed.

 

The image below shows the defects of the fusion of prominences in the face region:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 3–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with complaints of high fever and night sweats. His area is endemic for malaria. His blood sample is being investigated and two types of smears have been prepared as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Thick film is to identify parasite species
Both the films are used to identify parasite species
Thin film is used to find parasite when it is scanty
Thick film is used to find parasite when it is scanty

questions.solution:
In the given image, A is a thin smear and B is a thick smear. B/ Thick smear is used to find the malarial parasite when it is scanty. This is because more volume of blood is being scanned in the thick smear.

Both types of smears are made during microscopy for malaria detection. Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration.Thin smear is used to identify particular infecting species of Plasmodium.

Microscopy has high sensitivity and specificity, therefore it is the best method for diagnosis of malaria.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with congenital cataract. He also has the following lesions on his skin. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic appearance of a blueberry muffin baby. Blueberry muffin appearance along with the presentation of congenital cataract is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome caused by rubella virus.

Congenital rubella syndrome: It is characterized by cardiac defects, cataract, and deafness. Blueberry muffin appearance occurs due to purpuric lesions on the skin which are indicative of persistent dermal erythropoeisis in these infants.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 25-year-old primi has come for an antenatal ultrasound examination. The sonographic image appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the characteristic lemon sign on ultrasound which is seen in neural tube defects.

Signs of neural tube defect on targeted sonography:

  • Small biparietal diameter
  • Ventriculomegaly
  • Frontal bone scalloping or the lemon sign
  • Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna known as banana sign.

Other options:

  • Normal gestational sac shows double decidual sac. The empty head red arrow shows decidua and the filled head red arrow shows yolk sac
  • Intrauterine death shows spalding sign
  • Duodenal atresia shows double bubble sign

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Rukmini underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and the specimen obtained is given below. While going through her history which among the following could be the risk factor for the development of this type of gallstones?
questions.solution:
The above image shows black pigmented gallstones which can occur due to chronic hemolysis, cirrhosis, cystic fibrosis or ileal disease. Presence of mechanical heart valves can lead to chronic hemolysis.

Hyperlipidaemia, obesity, advancing age, female sex (hormones), contraceptive use are all risk factors for cholesterol stones.

Brown pigmented stones occur due to biliary stasis and infection.

questions.text: A woman comes for a consultation regarding contraceptive methods. Her gynecologist advises the use of the device shown in the image below. Which of the following is false regarding the device?

choices.text: The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 sq mm
Causes local inflammatory reaction in endometrium
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem and the horizontal arms. Its life span is 10 years.

Copper T-380A or Paragard is a copper-containing intrauterine contraceptive device. It contains 380 mm2 of copper and is composed of a stem wrapped with copper wire and two horizontal arms containing copper bracelets. Two strings extend from its base.

It acts by producing a localized inflammatory reaction in the endometrium. This activates lysosomes and other inflammatory mediators which are spermicidal. These inflammatory changes may also inhibit inflammation.
 
Contraindications to para guard include:
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine abnormality
  • Acute pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Postpartum endometritis
  • Wilson's disease
  • Known allergy to any component
  • Known or suspected genital tract malignancy
  • Unknown cause of genital tract bleeding.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male comes with symptoms suggestive of hypothyroidism. Your medicine junior resident proceeds to perform the thyroid examination. During this, he examines the patient as shown in the image below while instructing the patient to swallow. This method is the:
questions.solution:
The image shown depicts Crile’s method of thyroid palpation. In this method, the examiner places the thumb on the thyroid gland and asks the patient to swallow.

Lahey’s method (option B) The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally by the left hand, and the lobe is palpated with the right hand.

Kocher’s method (option C) is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

Pizzillo’s method (option D) is used for the inspection of the thyroid gland in obese and short-necked individuals. In this method, the hands are placed behind the head and the patient is asked to push his head against the clasped hands.

questions.text: During antibody screening for Hepatitis B infection, the following class of antibodies against HbcAg was detected in high titres in a patient. What is the most probable Hepatitis B infection status of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pentameric immunoglobulin, hence it is an IgM antibody. High titers of IgM antibodies signify a recent infection.

IgM antibody acts against the core antigen (IgM anti-Hbc) of Hepatitis B virus (HBV) and is predominant in acute infections. Later, it is replaced by IgG antibodies (IgG anti-Hbc).

Specific diagnosis of hepatitis B rests on the serological demonstration of the viral markers:

  • HBsAg is the first marker seen in the blood following infection and can be detected prior to the clinical manifestation and elevation of transaminases. Typically, they disappear within about two months of the start of clinical disease, but may sometimes persist for six months. Anti-HBs antibodies appear when the antigens are no longer detectable and they remain for very long periods. Anti-HBs are the protective antibody.
  • HBcAg cannot be demonstrated in circulation since it lies enclosed within the HBsAg coat, but its antibody, anti-HBc is the earliest marker seen in blood a week or two after the appearance of HBsAg. It remains for a lifetime and thus indicates a prior infection.
  • HBeAg appears in blood along with HBsAg or following its appearance. Circulating HBeAg is an indicator of active intrahepatic viral replication, and the presence of DNA polymerase, HBV DNA, and virions, reflect high infectivity.

Other options:

Option B: Remote HBV infection is characterized by the presence of IgG anti-Hbc antibodies.

Option C: People vaccinated against Hep B will have antibodies only against surface antigen HbsAg, and not against the core antigen. 

Option D: Hepatitis B carriers have IgG and HBsAg seen.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

-

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who presented with complaints of progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties has been diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the structures marked in the given image is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as B in the image represents dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), which is absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

Duchenne muscular dystrophy: It is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene, which is located at Xp21. The resultant lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which results in the progressive leakage of intracellular components.

Clinical features include progressive weakness and developmental delay. Pseudohypertrophy of calves and wasting of thigh muscles are seen. Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle is characteristically seen. It may be associated with dilated cardiomyopathy.

The image given below shows pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles.

Gower’s sign - The patient has to use hands and arms to "walk up" their own body from a squatting position. This indicates weakness of proximal muscles.

Diagnosis:

  • Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene
  • If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.
  • Histopathological examination of the muscle biopsy shows fatty replacement of muscle fibers.

The image given below shows the replacement of muscle fibers by adipose cells seen in DMD.

Treatment: Treatment of cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Eteplirsen and casimersen are the two new FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of DMD.

The complications of DMD include contractures, scoliosis, dilated cardiomyopathy, and malignant hyperthermia after anesthesia.

Prognosis: Death occurs usually at about 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to your clinic with complaints of slowly progressive reddish-brown skin lesions, with itching and scaling located predominantly over the non-sun-exposed parts of his body for the past couple of years.  On examination, there are bluish and reddish-brown ulcerated plaques and nodules. Histopathology reveals the following finding. Identify the structure marked by the arrow in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The arrow mark is pointing towards a collection of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis termed as Pautrier microabscess. This is a very important histopathologic feature of Mycosis fungoides which is the most common type of cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma is commonly seen in men more than 40 years of age. Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Other types include Sezary syndrome which occurs when the malignant cells from the skin enter the circulation. It is characterized by erythroderma.

Some types of microabscesses and their examples are given below:

Predominant cell Name of microabscess Disease
Neutrophilic microabscess

Papillary tip microabscess

Munroe's microabscess (superficial)

Spongiform pustules of Kogoj (deep)

Dermatitis Herpetiformis 

Psoriasis

Psoriasis
Lymphocytic microabscess Pautrier's microabscess Mycosis fungoides
Eosinophilic microabscess   Pemphigus vegetans

questions.text: You are assisting your professor during a breech delivery. You notice that she performs the maneuver given below to deliver the extended arms of the baby. This maneuver is known as
questions.solution:
The maneuver shown in the image is Lovset's maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

Modified Prague’s maneuver is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

The Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of the aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. If the structure marked in red arrow is injured, which of the following clinical manifestations would you expect?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in red is identified to be the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve). Injury to this nerve will result in loss of ankle eversion.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and ankle eversion
  • Diminishes sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved
  • High stepping gait is seen in this nerve injury

The common peroneal nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami. 

It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

The course of the common peroneal nerve is shown below.

Other options:

Plantar flexion is caused by the action of muscles gastrocnemius and soleus innervated by the tibial nerve. 

Ankle inversion is caused by the action of the tibialis posterior muscle innervated by the tibial nerve.

Ankle reflex (S1, S2) is characterised by the plantar flexion of the foot when the calcaneal tendon is struck with a percussion hammer. Thus it is lost in lesions of the tibial nerve.

questions.text: During your ward rounds, you observe a child with the abnormality seen in the image below. Which of the following risk factors would you suspect to be involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The image depicts caudal regression syndrome, which is associated with both overt and gestational diabetes mellitus in the mother.

This syndrome consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and/or the lumbar vertebrae. It occurs more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers (both preconceptionally and early in pregnancy) than in other infants although the exact mechanism is unclear. 

USG shows an abnormally short spine lacking normal lumbosacral curvature ending abruptly above the level of the iliac wings. The iliac wings appear abnormally close to each other like a shield due to the absence of the sacral vertebra. There may be associated VACTREL anomalies as well.

Other options:

  • Folic acid deficiency either as a result of dietary deficiency or due to antifolate drugs is associated with neural tube defects such as myelomeningocele, cardiac defects, and oral clefts.
  • Maternal use of lithium leads to an Ebstein anomaly and macrosomia. Chest X-ray showing a box-shaped heart in Ebstein anomaly is shown below: 
  • Maternal use of phenytoin causes fetal hydantoin syndrome characterized by digital hypoplasia, microcephaly, oral clefts, and other craniofacial abnormalities.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man developed nausea and jaundice over the past week. Laboratory investigations revealed an active hepatitis B infection. Which of the following liver pathology findings is depicted in the slide below?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman's bodies and they represent apoptosis.

Councilman's bodies are acidophilic bodies, which represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis. They are mainly seen in acute viral hepatitis.

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which the cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells' nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 

Mechanism of apoptosis: There are two distinct pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway

The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • There are several proteins in the mitochondria that can induce apoptosis. These include cytochrome c and some proteins that neutralize the endogenous inhibitors of apoptosis.
  • The permeability of the mitochondria is controlled by a family of proteins called the BCL-2 family, which act as sensors.
  • These sensors are activated when the cells are deprived of growth factors and other survival signals, are exposed to agents that damage the DNA, or accumulate a large number of misfolded proteins.
  • These activated sensors, in turn, activate the proapoptotic molecules like BAX and BAK, which form channels in the mitochondrial membrane, through which cytochrome c and other mitochondrial proteins escape into the cytosol and cause activation of caspase-9, which, in turn, leads to the activation of the caspase cascade and, eventually, apoptosis of the cell.
  • On the other hand, if all the growth factors and other survival signals are present, then they produce more antiapoptotic members of the BH1-4 family like the BCL2, MCL 1, and BCL-XL. These proteins limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

The death-receptor (extrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • Death receptors are surface molecules that are members of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor family, like TNF 1 and Fas (CD 95).
  • These receptors are expressed on the surface of many cells and can trigger apoptosis. In the cytoplasmic region, these receptors have a “death domain.”
  • Fas ligand (FasL) is a membrane protein expressed mainly on activated T-lymphocytes. Fas-FasL interactions are required for thymic medullary negative selection. Defective interactions also cause the autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. 
  • When these T-cells recognize Fas-expressing targets, Fas molecules are cross-linked by FasL and bind adaptor proteins via the death domain.
  • These, in turn, recruit and activate caspase-8 and -10.
  • In many cell types, caspase-8 and -10 may cleave and activate a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family called Bid, thus feeding into the mitochondrial pathway.
  • The combined activation of both pathways delivers a lethal blow to the cell.
  • Cellular proteins, notably, a caspase antagonist called FLIP, block the activation of caspases downstream of the death receptors. Interestingly, some viruses produce homologues of FLIP, and it is suggested that this is a mechanism that viruses use to keep infected cells alive.
  • The death receptor pathway is involved in the elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes and in the killing of target cells by some cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain. A barium swallow study was done and the findings are given below. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The barium swallow image shows a bird beak appearance which is characteristic of achalasia cardia. Secondary achalasia is associated with Chagas disease which is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi infection and not Trypanosoma brucei.

Achalasia is characterized by the triad of incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, increased lower esophageal sphincter tone, and aperistalsis of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is rare. It results from the degeneration of nitric oxide–producing neurons that normally induce lower esophageal sphincter relaxation.

Secondary achalasia is associated with the following conditions:

  • Chagas disease
  • Diabetic autonomic neuropathy
  • Infiltrative disorders such as malignancy, amyloidosis, and sarcoidosis
  • Systemic sclerosis
  • Lesions of dorsal motor nuclei (e.g., following polio)
  • Down syndrome
  • Allgrove (triple A) syndrome

Manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis and it also distinguishes achalasia from other potential esophageal motility disorders.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with the following finding. His oxygen saturation is 80% despite a good respiratory effort, a clear airway, and bilateral breath sounds. Oxygen administration via nasal cannula did not improve oxygen saturation. Methemoglobinemia was suspected. Which of the following should be given in the emergency room?
questions.solution:
The given image showing cyanosis (bluish lips), along with a history of decreased oxygen saturation, supports the suspicion of methemoglobinemia. IV methylene blue is the preferred treatment.

Normally the iron in hemoglobin is stored in ferrous (Fe2+) state. When this iron is in oxidized form (Fe3+), the hemoglobin is called methemoglobin. Methemoglobin does not bind to oxygen readily, and is not able to deliver the oxygen to the peripheral tissues. This causes tissue hypoxia and leftward shifting of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

Acquired methemoglobinemia can occur due to a number of drugs, such as nitrites (option B) dapsone, local anesthetics such as benzocaine, and antimalarials such as chloroquine and primaquine (option D). It presents as cyanosis that does not respond to oxygen administration. Therefore, oxygen administration via face mask (option A) would not help in this patient. Methemoglobin assay is used to determine the exact levels of methemoglobin in the blood. Patients are treated with IV methylene blue or vitamin C administration.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient presents with a history of chronic fatigue. He has no significant past medical or surgical history and he is on a strict vegan diet. His peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario along with the image is highly suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. In the given image, the peripheral smear shows cabot rings and basophilic stippling.

Megaloblastic anemia is a type of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation. The causes include

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Folate deficiency
  • Drugs (Methotrexate)

In this stem, the likely cause is vitamin B12 deficiency as the patient is a strict vegan. Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Other causes of B12 deficiency includes

  • Malabsorption (Pernicious anemia)
  • Total or partial gastrectomy
  • Ileal resection
  • Tropical sprue

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (SACDSC). Seen in only B12 deficiency.
  • Psychiatric disturbances

The peripheral smear shows oval macrocytes, anisocytosis, and hypersegmented neutrophils (more than 5 nuclear lobes).

Other features of ineffective erythropoiesis seen in megaloblastic anemias include:

  • Howell-Jolly bodies: Nuclear remnants within red cells that are usually single, round, dark purple-red in color, and peripheral in location.

 

  • Basophilic stippling: Blue granules of various sizes dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell, they represent ribosomal precipitates.
  • Cabot rings: Red cell inclusions appearing as fine, purple filamentous loops or figures of eight forms, presumed to be remnants of mitotic spindles.

The image below shows basophilic stippling and Cabot rings:

questions.text: A patient who had a parotid surgery now has complaints of sweating on his face whenever he smells or tastes food. The nerve responsible for this is shown in the image below. Identify the structure marked X in the image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the image is the middle meningeal artery. The nerve marked in the image is the auriculotemporal nerve. The auriculotemporal nerve arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve and encircles the middle meningeal artery at its origin.

Gustatory sweating is known as Frey’s syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule. During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands (great auricular nerve). This results in sweating, warmth and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man sustained a traumatic head injury. The following image was taken after he was asked to look straight. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is right 6th nerve palsy as the image shows esotropia and a limitation of abduction of the right eye. 

The 6th cranial nerve or abducens nerve supplies the lateral rectus muscle which is an abductor of the eye. Its lesion cause esotropia due to the unopposed action of the medial rectus.  The 3rd cranial nerve or oculomotor nerve supplies the medial rectus which is an adductor of the eye.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is asked to look left, the lesion would be in the left eye. The left lateral rectus would be affected due to a left abducens nerve palsy.

Other options: 

Option A: 3rd or oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis due to weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris, abduction and depression in the primary position (due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique). Limited adduction, elevation and depression due to medial rectus, superior rectus and inferior oblique weakness. Pupil will be dilated pupil with defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

Option B: 4th or trochlear nerve supplies the superior oblique muscle and its palsy causes hypertropia, limited depression and extorsion of the affected eye. 

Option D: Horizontal gaze palsy occurs due to a lesion in the parapontine reticular formation. This leads to ipsilateral lateral rectus and contralateral medial rectus weakness. It is characterized by the inability to look in the direction of the lesion. 

Related Pearl: Functional components of cranial nerves

questions.text: A patient is unable to speak fluently. He understands what is being told/ asked and he knows what he wants to say but when he tries he is only able to make noises. He cannot repeat anything being said to him either. Which of the areas marked in the image below is damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The ability to comprehend spoken language and loss of fluency along with impairment of repetition indicates Broca’s aphasia due to damage to the Broca’s area marked as C in the image.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient with dyspepsia, weight loss, and melena is being evaluated with a barium upper gastrointestinal study. An outpouching with a smooth, deep ulcer crater is seen along the lesser gastric curvature and is diagnosed to be a benign gastric ulcer. Which of the following radiological feature is suggestive of a benign gastric ulcer?
questions.solution:
The radiological feature that is suggestive of a benign gastric ulcer is Hampton's line.

Hampton’s line is usually a 1 mm thin, radiolucent line seen at the neck of the ulcer that represents a rim of undermined mucosa, seen in barium studies. Hampton’s line is a feature of benign gastric ulcers.

Other features of a benign ulcer include-

  • Location on the lesser curvature
  • Extends beyond the gastric wall
  • Smooth ulcer mound - representative of edema
  • Smooth folds reaching up to the edge of the ulcer
  • Heals completely

Other options:

Option A- Hampton's hump is a radiologic sign associated with pulmonary embolism. It consists of a shallow wedge-shaped opacity in the periphery of the lung with its base against the pleural surface.

Option C- Carman meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers and describes the lenticular shape of barium in the shallow/flat malignant ulcer, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen (benign ulcers are concave towards the lumen). Other features of malignant ulcers include irregular ulcer base, nodular mound, and thickened, interrupted, and fused folds around the ulcer.

Option D- Ram’s horn sign is seen in Crohn’s disease of the stomach leading to deformity of the antrum with a tubular shape, conical narrowing, and limited distensibility of the stomach, resembling the shape of a horn.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man was diagnosed to have a brain tumor. The histological appearance of the excised tumor is shown in the image given below. What is the isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutation status of this patient most likely to be?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the histological image showing extensive necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, is suggestive of glioblastoma, which is commonly associated with IDH-wild-type mutations.

Gliomas constitute the most common type of primary brain tumor. They are classified as follows:

  • Astrocytomas
    • Localized type- eg. pilocytic astrocytoma (grade 1)
    • Diffuse infiltrating type- Can be IDH mutant or IDH wild type
      • Diffuse astrocytoma (grade 2)
      • Anaplastic astrocytoma (grade 3)
      • Glioblastoma (grade 4)
  • Oligodendrogliomas- IDH mutant, 1p/19q co-deletion
  • Ependymomas- NF2 gene mutations
Glioblastoma affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor gene (EGFR) are implicated in the pathogenesis. The majority of the tumors (90%) have IDH wild-type mutation, and the remaining have IDH mutant type.

Clinically, the patient presents with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits, depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages.

 

Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—a dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

 

They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere. 

Radiologically, glioblastomas appear as a large ring-enhancing heterogeneous mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes.

The image given below shows MRI findings seen in glioblastomas. Note the butterfly morphology of the tumor:

 

Standard treatment includes surgery followed by a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy with temozolomide following surgical resection. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody, may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A nurse was diagnosed with varicose veins. On examination, the following was seen. There was no associated skin change or venous ulcer. According to the CEAP classification system, she would be classified as
questions.solution:
According to CEAP classification, Varicose veins without skin changes or ulcer comes under the clinical class of C2.

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes,

  • C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  • C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  • C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

With symptoms attributable to venous disease

A

Absence of symptoms attributable to venous disease

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Es

Esi

Ec

Anatomic classification (A)

As

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Pr

Pr,o

Pn

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with a history of itchiness in the skin folds for the past 5 years. He denies any prior treatment but is now concerned about the hardening of skin lesions as shown. Which of the following is the likely secondary change involved here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows lichenification. Lichenification is a secondary skin lesion characterized by hyperpigmentation, thickening of the skin, and exaggerated skin markings. It is a feature of chronic eczema.

Other options 

Atrophy is marked as shiny skin with appearance of wrinkling

Gangrene occurs due to loss of vascular supply resulting in death of tissue

Papilloma is projection of nipple like mass from skin surface

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: A 4 year old boy is brought to the opd with cough, fever, and swelling of the neck. His parents give a history of incomplete immunization of the child. The following lesion is seen on examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dirty white pseudomembrane seen in diphtheria. It is caused by corynebacterium diphtheria.

The incidence of diphtheria has reduced because of immunization but it may be seen in children with incomplete or no immunization.

Management includes immediate administration of diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotic therapy.

The given image shows bull neck appearance seen in diphtheria.

The given image shows mumps:

The given image shows tonsillitis:

The given image shows oral candidiasis. Note that the lesions are spread all over the oral cavity and not localized around the tonsils like diphtheria. Oral candidiasis can also occur on the tongue.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the rheumatology clinic with multiple joint pains. Her laboratory reports reveal the presence of anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibodies. Which part of the spine is most commonly affected in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of anti-CCP antibodies point towards the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The most commonly affected part of the spine in RA is cervical.

The atlantoaxial joint - C1 and C2 is the most commonly affected part of the spine in rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Other joints commonly affected are - bilateral and symmetrically involved:

  • Metacarpophalangeal joints
  • Wrists
  • Proximal interphalangeal joints
  • Metatarsophalangeal joints

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: Which of the following wastes are disposed in the bag shown below?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows a red coloured bag which is used to dispose contaminated wastes (recyclable) such as tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles) and gloves.

Option B: Anatomical wastes go into yellow non-chlorinated plastic bags.
Option C: Soiled wastes go into yellow coloured non-chlorinated plastic bags.
Option D: Sharp wastes go into white puncture proof, leak proof, tamper proof containers.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: The following sign is seen in a patient with spinal cord injury. What is the most likely level of lesion in the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Beevor’s sign indicating a spinal cord lesion at the level T10-T12.

Beevor’s sign is the abnormal upward movement of the umbilicus on abdominal wall contraction in the supine position. This is because a lesion in the T10-T12 level of the spinal cord paralyzes the lower abdominal muscles but the upper abdominal muscles are normally resulting in the upward movement of the umbilicus.

questions.text: During ward rounds, the neonatologist tries to pick up the newborn. You observe the sign as shown in the image given below. The presence of this sign is considered abnormal after ________.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pull-to-sit maneuver being performed and there is a complete head lag on picking up the child. The presence of this sign is abnormal if it persists beyond 20 weeks.

In the newborn, the head completely lags and the back is rounded. The head lag disappears once neck control is achieved and the child starts to flex his head when trying to pick up from the supine position.

The head control first begins to develop at 6 weeks, and there is a slight lag at 12 weeks. Complete neck control is attained by 20 weeks, after which, the infant lifts the head from the supine position when about to be pulled.

Related Pearl: Gross motor milestones
