questions.text: A 45-year-old hypertensive obese man was diagnosed with Bilateral renal tumors. Investigations showed loss of 3p25 chromosomal DNA. Histopathology of the tumours will likely show which of the following appearances?
questions.solution:
VHL syndrome is associated with 3p25 loss. It is associated with bilateral clear cell neoplasms of kidney corresponding to Figure 4.

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is characterized by a predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina. Hundreds of bilateral renal cysts, often multiple, clear cell carcinomas develop in 40% to 60% of affected persons. Those with VHL syndrome inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. A "second hit" can lead to manifestations

Manifestations of the von Hippel-Lindau Disease

ORGAN SYSTEM 

 LESION

Eye 

 Retinal angiomas (benign)

CNS

 Hemangioblastomas (benign)

Kidney 

Clear-cell renal cell carcinoma

Renal cyst

Adrenal gland 

 Pheochromocytoma

Pancreas 

Neuroendocrine tumors (benign and malignant)

Pancreatic cysts

Epididymis 

 Cystadenoma

Ear 

 Endolymphatic sac tumor


Other options:

2: Papillary RCC- Histology is characterized by a papillary growth pattern and the presence of Psammoma bodies

3: Chromophobe RCC- Histology is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm. Plant-like cells/resin-like nuclei with a perinuclear halo are seen.

1: Medullary carcinoma- Histology displays various morphologies including reticular, yolk sac, or adenoid cystic growth patterns, and sometimes shows neoplastic cells admixed with neutrophils in a desmoplastic background. 

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A male patient presented with discoloration of his nails over the past 6 months. The findings of the physical examination are shown below. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice for treating the pathology depicted in this image?

choices.text: Binding to ergosterol and altering membrane functions
Formation of pores in cell membrane
Inhibition of squalene epoxidase involved in ergosterol synthesis

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing the yellowish discoloration of his nails, is suggestive of onychomycosis. Terbinafine is used for the treatment of this condition. The mechanism of action of terbinafine is the inhibition of squalene epoxidase, which is involved in ergosterol synthesis.

Squalene epoxidase is an enzyme that converts squalene to squalene epoxide. Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of squalene epoxidase, an early-step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene, which is toxic to the organism.

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases of onychomycosis.

Treatment of onychomycosis:

First-line drug Duration
Oral terbinafine - 250 mg/day

Fingernails - 6 weeks

Toenails - 12 weeks
Oral itraconazole- 400 mg/day for 1 week

Fingernails - regimen repeated every month for 2 to 3 months

Toenails - regimen repeated every month for 3 to 4 months

It is observed that terbinafine, given as one 250 mg tablet daily for adults is somewhat more effective than itraconazole for nail onychomycosis. Oral griseofulvin dose of 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails) is used as a second-line drug.

Topical treatment with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine can be used in mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non-linear superficial onychomycosis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 

ALL is more common in childhood. Clinical features of ALL include:

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

  Lymphoblasts  Myeloblasts 
Blast population Homogeneous Heterogeneous, with the exception of the undifferentiated form 
Size Variable, mainly small  Variable, mainly large 
Nucleus Central, mainly round; sometimes indented. 
 		 Eccentric, round, oval, or angulated; sometimes convoluted, particularly in the form with a monocytic component 
Chromatin Fine, with dispersed condensation. 
Very condensed in small lymphoblasts 		 Fine, granular, delicately dispersed 
Nucleoli Absent in small lymphoblasts. 
Sometimes indistinct 		 Present. Often large and prominent, double or triple 
Cytoplasm Scanty and basophilic.
Sometimes with a single long projection (hand-mirror cell) 		 Variable. 
Abundant in monoblasts, 
with protrusions in erythroblasts and megakaryoblasts 
Granules Rarely present. Negative for peroxidase, esterases, and toluidine blue  Present in forms with differentiation and positive with cytochemical stains
  • Peroxidase in the neutrophil and eosinophil lineages
  • Nonspecific esterase in the monocyte lineage 
Auer rods Absent  Can be present. 
Typically present in the hyper granular promyelocytic form 
Vacuoles Can be present Can be present. 
Almost always present in forms with a monocytic component 

The image given below shows lymphoblasts.

The image given below shows myeloblasts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent dilatation and curettage previously, now presents with amenorrhea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. HSG revealed a honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity. Her hysteroscopy image is as shown below. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is false?

choices.text: It occurs due to endometrial damage causing the formation of synechiae
The risk of this condition is lowest with postabortal or postpartum uterine curettage
It can cause recurrent abortions due to inadequate placentation
Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is useful in management

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and hysteroscopy is suggestive of Asherman syndrome and the risk of developing it is the highest if D&C is done in the postabortal or postpartum period. In postpartum hemorrhage, a greater area of the uterine wall is curetted, because the postpartum uterus is larger and bulkier.

Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following pregnancy-related curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion. Damage may also result from other uterine surgery and infection associated with an intrauterine device.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients can develop amenorrhea (in less severe cases), hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss due to inadequate placentation.

Treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis followed by insertion of Cu T to prevent adhesion formations and a combination of estrogen and progesterone is given to rebuild endometrium.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male was referred to an orthopaedic surgeon with limited painful movements with swelling around the right elbow region for the past several months. He has a history of trauma to the region in the distant past. An X-ray was taken and appears as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The pathology seen in the x-ray is myositis ossificans.

Myositis ossificans is defined as ectopic benign heterotopic ossification, usually occurring within large muscles.

It is most commonly seen after dislocation of the elbow or a blow to the brachialis, deltoid, or quadriceps. The patient presents with gross restriction of range of movements and should be advised not to massage the site as it promotes ossification.

Treatment involves joint rest in the position of function until the pain subsides, followed by gentle movements. After a few months if the pain and restriction persist then the bony mass is excised.

Indomethacin and radiotherapy may prevent a recurrence.

questions.text: A young woman undergoing vaginal delivery started bleeding after the expulsion of the placenta. Medical management was unsuccessful in arresting the bleeding. So the device shown below was used. What amount of fluid should be instilled into this device to arrest hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Bakri balloon. 300-500 ml of fluid should be instilled into it for it to be effective in arresting hemorrhage

A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity and stop bleeding in patients with atonic PPH (postpartum hemorrhage) who are unresponsive to medical management. The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterine cavity.

Insertion is achieved with help of two or three team members:

  • One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure
  • Second member to place the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilize it.
  • The third member instils fluid to inflate the balloon. Inflated rapidly by infusing at least 150 mL followed by further installation over a few minutes for a total of 300 to 500 mL to arrest hemorrhage.

The balloon is usually removed after 12 hours of insertion. It is successful in most cases of atonic PPH and helps to avoid hysterectomy in the majority of cases. 

Segstaken­ Blakemore, Rusch, and ebb balloons, Foley's catheter, and condom catheters can also be used instead. In the technique where Foley's catheter is utilised, a 24F-30F size catheter with a 30ml balloon is used, the tip is guided into the uterine cavity and filled with 60-80ml of saline.  Once the bleeding subsides, the catheter can be removed after 12 -24 hours.

The following are the steps used in controlling the postpartum haemorrhage:

  • Feel the uterus to know the cause of the haemorrhage. If the uterus feels flabby, bleeding is likely to be due to atonicity. If it is firm and contracted, it is likely to be traumatic in origin.
  • In case of an atonic uterus, massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin drips or methergine. 
  • If the uterus remains atonic, manual exploration of the uterus is done for removing any retained placental fragments. Blood transfusion is started and oxytocin drips are continued. Other uterotonic agents can also be given.
  • Uterine massage and bimanual compression
  • Uterine tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter (balloon tamponade)
  • Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:
    • Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture
    • Ligation of uterine arteries
    • Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis
    • Ligation of internal iliac artery
    • Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel
  •   Hysterectomy

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient was diagnosed with carcinoma of the breast and is set to undergo radical mastectomy with dissection of levels 1, 2 and 3 lymph nodes. Which of the following represents level 3 lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes marked as 1 belong to the level 3 axillary nodes.

Lymph nodes are divided into different levels on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor.

  • Level 1 lymph nodes: Lateral to the pectoralis minor
  • Level 2 lymph nodes: Superficial or deep to the pectoralis minor
  • Level 3 lymph nodes: Medial to or above the upper border of the pectoralis minor

 

Another method of axillary lymph node classification, as shown in the image below, is based on the anatomical regions that the specific nodes drain.

It can be classified into 5 groups- apical, central, lateral, anterior, and posterior. The apical group receives lymph from the other 4 groups, as well as from the upper part of the breast on the same side.

The image below demonstrates this method of lymph node grouping-

Related Pearl: Breast Lump Evaluation

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Tumor (T)

Description
Tx

T0

No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS
T1

1mic ≤ 0.1 cm

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – Inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes

Stages T, N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0

Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0

# Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

* Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage 4d) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of the breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presents with a lower GI bleed. Sigmoidoscopy shows ulcers in the sigmoid. The histopathological section of the biopsy specimen is shown below.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcer and the clinical scenario are suggestive of intestinal amoebiasis. The appropriate treatment is intravenous metronidazole.

The flask-shaped amoebic ulcer is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amoebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region.

questions.text: A young male patient came to the clinic with pigmentation of the mouth as shown in the image below. He also complained of recurrent abdominal pain. After a detailed evaluation, multiple hamartomatous polyps were found in the jejunum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Peutz Jegher's syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter. Female patients are encouraged to attend breast and cervical screening.

Surgery is indicated in cases where there is bleeding, obstruction, intussusception, or adenomatous changes of the polyp. If surgery is done for these indications, attempts should be made to remove as much as polyps as possible. 

Other options:

Turcot syndrome (option A) is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis and constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors (including medulloblastoma and glioblastomas)

Lynch syndrome (option B) is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is due to defective mismatch repair of DNA.

Cowden disease (option C) is characterized by polyps of the colon or stomach with mucocutaneous lesions, thyroid adenomas and goiter, fibroadenomas and fibrocystic disease of the breast, and uterine leiomyomas.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented at 29 weeks of gestation presented with a 5-day history of severe, sharp, and constant abdominal pain. An ultrasound scan showed a uterine fibroid. A subsequent MRI revealed changes in the fibroid consistent with the image below. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Removal of fibroid at caesarean section
Termination of pregnancy by induction of labour
Laparotomy for removal of fibroid alone

questions.solution:
The given MRI shows a subserosal uterine mass with a peripheral high signal due to hemorrhage. The clinical scenario and the image suggest red degeneration of the fibroid, which is managed conservatively with analgesics.

Myomectomy at cesarean section carries the risk of uncontrolled bleeding and hence is not done except in the case of a pedunculated fibroid.

Red degeneration is a complication (secondary change) of fibroids that often develop during pregnancy or over the age of 40. The myoma becomes tense and causes severe abdominal pain with constitutional upset and fever. The fibroid assumes a peculiar purple-red color and a fishy odor.

The image below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration- heterogeneous mass on T2 (a) with peripheral high signal on T1 (b):


Hyaline degeneration is the most common secondary change whereas sarcomatous change is the least common.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: An oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a 30-year-old athlete was recorded. If curve 3 represents the dissociation curve during rest, how would the graph shift if he was exercising?
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, during exercise, the oxygen hemoglobin curve shifts considerably towards the right and is denoted by the curve 4.

Curve 3 represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve during rest. 

Conditions that cause a right shift (curve 3 to curve 4) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

Conditions that cause a left shift (curve 3 to curve 2)  in the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • ↑ pH of the blood
  • ↓ in the temperature of the body

Curve 1 represents the Myoglobin-O2 binding curve. It is a rectangular hyperbola (unlike a sigmoid curve of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve). This is because it only has a single oxygen binding site. It is present in muscles in large amounts and can provide oxygen to muscles even at low blood oxygen levels.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting 2,3 -DPG

↑ in 2, 3-DPG ↓ in 2, 3-DPG
  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Anemia
  • Acclimitization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid hormone
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise
  • Stored blood
  • Acidosis

questions.text: A young woman is found to have the following finding during the abdominal CT scan. She has no specific symptoms and this was an incidental finding on her imaging. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It has a risk of malignant transformation
Asymptomatic patients do not require any surgical intervention
FNH always has a true capsule
This is the most common liver lesion

questions.solution:
The given CT image shows the presence of a hypervascular liver lesion with a central non-enhancing scar. This is most likely to be focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

FNH is a benign tumor of the liver which is commonly seen in young women. The exact cause is unknown. 

The patients are usually asymptomatic and the tumor is found incidentally during the imaging studies or laparotomy. A contrast-enhanced CT image shows a hypervascular lesion with a central scar. FNH lacks a true capsule

These tumors do not have the risk of malignant transformation and therefore asymptomatic patients do not require any surgical intervention. Surgical resection can be indicated if the patients have symptoms.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is undergoing investigations for excessive and spontaneous bruising. Direct microscopy of urine revealed a peculiar finding that led the physician to suspect Fabry’s disease. What is that finding?
questions.solution:
In a patient with Fabry’s disease, maltese cross urinary casts can be seen.

Urine analysis in Fabry’s disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

Maltese cross appearance elsewhere:

  • Short range gun wounds
  • Peripheral smear of Babesiosis

Other options:

  • A - Waxy cast
  • B - RBC cast
  • C - WBC cast

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 5-day-old neonate born at term presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. The chest x-ray of the neonate is shown below. The given congenital heart defect is seen due to the developmental defect of _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests the neonate has a cyanotic heart defect and the given x-ray shows figure of 8 or snowman appearance characteristic of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC).

TAPVC refers to a condition in which pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly. This results in anomalous drainage of pulmonary venous blood flow into the systemic venous circulation. It is a cyanotic heart disease with features of congestive heart failure. The patients are irritable and have failure to thrive. 

The following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into the superior vena cava or the left innominate vein.
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into the portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, the brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium. It is shown in the image below.

Other options: (Differentials for cyanotic heart disease) 

Option A: Tricuspid valvular defect is seen in Ebstein's anomaly where the valve is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged right atrium resulting in severe right-sided cardiomegaly giving a box-shape heart appearance. 

Option C: Aorta and pulmonary artery defects are seen in the transposition of great arteries. Here, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk from the left ventricle. The x-ray shows cardiomegaly with cardiac contours which appear like an egg on the side. 

Option D: Truncus arteriosus is a single artery arising from the heart. This single artery supplies pulmonary, systemic, and coronary circulation. It is always associated with a VSD. The truncus overrides the defect and receives blood from both the right and left ventricles.

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in cardiology

Sign

Boot shaped heart/ Coeur-en-sabot
Fallot’s tetralogy
Gooseneck sign
Endocardial cushion defects
Box-shaped heart
Ebstein's anomaly
Jug handle appearance
Primary pulmonary artery hypertension
“3” like appearance of the aorta
Coarctation of aorta
Egg-on-string appearance
Transposition of great vessels
Egg in cup appearance, Pericardial calcification
Constrictive pericarditis
Snowman’s heart, Cottage loaf appearance, Figure of Eight appearance
Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
Scimitar sign
Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return
Calcification in the heart wall
Carcinoid syndrome

Atherosclerosis, Syphilis
Hilar dance on fluoroscopy

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation

Transposition of great vessels

Tricuspid atresia

Tetrology of Fallot

questions.text: An underweight adolescent girl is found to have the following finding on ocular examination. What is the WHO grade for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bitot spot, which is a feature seen in vitamin A deficiency. According to the WHO grading of xerophthalmia, Bitot spots are classified as 1B.

Bitot spots are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva on either side of the cornea.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: You have collected the blood sample of a patient in the following vacutainer. Which of the following tests is to be performed in this sample?
questions.solution:
The image shows a grey coloured tube which is used to measure blood glucose.

Grey tube contains flouride/oxalate which are antiglycolytic agents that preserve glucose for upto 5 days.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 30-year-old man developed abdominal pain for which he was being evaluated. You notice the following in his CECT.  What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a horseshoe kidney, as indicated by the fused pole of the kidney anterior to the aorta. It is prone to obstruction, reflux, and stone formation (the likely cause of pain in this case)

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys with a male preponderance. Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of the kidneys usually lies in front of the L3 vertebra due to the arrest of ascent.

The common associations of horseshoe kidneys are:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux
  • Wilms Tumor
  • Multicystic Dysplastic Kidney
  • Turner’s Syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant woman in labor started bleeding profusely immediately after artificial rupture of membranes and emergency LSCS was performed. The placenta of the patient is given below. Identify the type of placenta.
questions.solution:
The type of placenta shown in the image is the velamentous placenta. The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the fetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

The scenario described is suggestive of vasa previa, in which part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination.

Battledore placenta: The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.

Succenturiate placenta: One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

Circumvallate placenta - The fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with 8-month history shortness of breath and non-productive cough. On physical examination, fine crackles are heard bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show an FVC of 78% and FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. CT scan of the chest is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary fibrosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given the symptoms of shortness of breath and persistent nonproductive cough, bilateral inspiratory crackles, pulmonary function test (PFT) results, and imaging findings.

The image shows the presence of honeycombing (black arrows), traction bronchiectasis (white arrow), and a reticular pattern (black dotted arrows). The lesions are typically located along subpleural regions.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common cause of interstitial lung disease (ILD) of unknown cause. It is defined as a progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown etiology, occurring in adults. It is associated with a histological or radiological pattern known as usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP). UIP is the typical pathological finding in patients with suspected IPF.

Patients with UIP typically present in their sixth and seventh decades of life. Men are affected more commonly than women. PFTs in patients with pulmonary fibrosis show a restrictive pattern, which is characterized by decreased total lung capacity (TLC), forced vital capacity (FVC), residual volumes (RV), and a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio of >0.7.

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) demonstrates a characteristic pattern of peripheral (subpleural) and bibasilar reticular opacities associated with architectural distortion, including honeycomb changes and traction bronchiectasis.

Classification of ILD (based on the histopathological pattern observed on lung biopsy)

Histologic pattern Clinical syndrome
Usual interstitial pneumonia Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
Desquamative interstitial Pneumonia Desquamative interstitial pneumonia
Acute interstitial pneumonia Hamman–Rich syndrome
Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
Respiratory bronchiolitis–associated lung disease Respiratory bronchiolitis– associated interstitial lung disease

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text:
A elderly hypertensive man presented with unilateral weakness of upper limbs and slurring of speech. NCCT scan was done to reveal the following sign. What is the name of the sign?

NCCT - Non-contrast computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of unilateral weakness of upper limbs and slurring of speech in a hypertensive man is suggestive of stroke. The NCCT image is showing hyperdense MCA sign i.e. occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA) due to a hyperdense embolus. This sign is indicative of ischemic stroke. 

After the clinical diagnosis of stroke is made, an emergency evaluation should be made to check patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs), hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia. The main goal is to distinguish it as either an ischemic stroke or hemorrhagic stroke with the help of an emergency noncontrast head CT. 

The following signs of acute ischemia can be seen on CT:

  • Blurring of the gray/white junction and effacement of the sulci due to ischemic swelling of the tissues.
  • Blurring of the margins of the gray matter structures
  • In cases of internal carotid artery occlusion or middle cerebral artery main segment (M1) occlusion, intraluminal clot may be seen as a focal hyperdensity, known as the hyperdense MCA sign or hyperdense dot sign.

Management includes:

  • Reduction of blood pressure when: BP >220/120 mmHg, presence of malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg in a patient planned for intravenous thrombolysis.
  • Serum glucose maintained between 60 mg/dL and 180 mg/dL.
  • IV mannitol and water restriction may be required to reduce edema which can lead to a mass effect.
  • Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (0.9 mg/kg), tenecteplase (0.25 mg/kg) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset).
  • Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.
  • Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 300 mg should be started within 48 hours of acute ischemic stroke.

Other options:

Option A: String sign of Kantor is seen in Crohn's disease. It refers to the string like appearance of a contrast filled bowel loop due to luminal narrowing.

Option B: Eye of tiger sign is seen due to T2 hypointensity in the globus pallidus with a longitudinal stripe of high intensity. It is commonly seen in pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) but is not pathognomic of the condition. It can be seen in Wilson's disease, atypical parkinsonism and organophosphate poisoning.

Option D: The dural tail sign is seen in meningioma due to thickening and enhancement of dura.

Related Pearl: Target BP in hypertensive patients- European Society of Cardiology guidelines 2018

Age group Hypertension Coexisting diabetes Coexisting chronic kidney disease Coexisting coronary artery disease Coexisting stroke/ TIA

18-65 years

(Target systolic range- if tolerated)

120-130 mmHg

120-130 mmHg

130-140 mmHg

120-130 mmHg

120-130 mmHg

65-79 years

(Target systolic range- if tolerated)

130-139 mmHg

130-139 mmHg

130-139 mmHg

130-139 mmHg

130-139 mmHg
Office diastolic measurement 70-79mmHg 70-79mmHg 70-79mmHg  70-79mmHg  70-79mmHg

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: During your ward postings in medicine, you see a patient in ICU with the following finding. On close examination, you find the absence of pulsation and abdominojugular reflux. Which of the following may be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows grossly elevated JVP in an elderly man. Absence of pulsation and abdominojugular reflux points towards a diagnosis of lung cancer causing SVC obstruction.

The elevated JVP due to SVC obstruction does not reflect the right atrial pressure and since it is not in continuation with RA, the abdominojugular reflux will be negative as well.

 

Other options:

Heart failure shows elevated JVP with a sustained abdominojugular reflux as the heart is unable to pump blood and has pooling which gives rise to elevation in JVP.

Constrictive pericarditis prevents effective relaxation of heart and shows elevated JVP with kussmaul's sign.

Complete heart block results in canon waves.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 29-year-old man who has come for his annual health checkup is found to have the following finding in the chest x-ray. His clinical examination is quite unremarkable and his abdomen is soft. You probe him regarding any significant symptoms and he responds that he has no complaints and has come only because the health check was free. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows pseudopneumoperitoneum which is seen in Chilaiditi’s syndrome. 

It is the harmless and asymptomatic interposition of the large bowel between the liver and diaphragm. It has to be differentiated from pneumoperitoneum because it does not require any intervention.

Features that suggest a Chilaiditi syndrome are:

  • The gas between the liver and diaphragm.
  • Rugal folds within the gas suggesting that it is within the bowel and not free.

Other options:

Pneumoperitoneum (option A) appears as subdiaphragmatic free gas.

Pneumopericardium (option B) appears as a dark line around the heart. (Indicated by the solid white arrow.)

questions.text: A 32-year-old diabetic man was undergoing a routine check-up. ECG revealed ST changes as given below. Repeated cardiac biomarkers were found to be within the normal range. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows coved ST-segment elevation of V1-V3, followed by a negative T wave (Brugada sign), which points to a diagnosis of Brugada syndrome. A coved ST segment has a downward concavity.

Brugada syndrome is an inherited sodium channelopathy (SCN5A mutation) most commonly seen in Southeast Asian males. The age of presentation is usually 40 years. This syndrome is characterised by an increased risk of sudden cardiac death due to polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

To establish a diagnosis of ST-elevation MI (Option B) and NSTEMI (Option D), a positive and significant rise in cardiac biomarkers (troponins) is necessary along with one of the following features:

  • Symptoms of ischemia
  • New ST-T elevation or LBBB (not for NSTEMI)
  • Pathologic Q waves (STEMI, old infarcts)
  • Imaging evidence of loss of myocardium viability
  • Intracoronary thrombus identified on angioplasty or autopsy

Since we do not have a typical rise and fall pattern of cardiac biomarkers, in this case, a diagnosis of acute ST-elevation MI and NSTEMI is less likely.

Causes of ST-T changes apart from acute MI:

  • Acute pericarditis (Option C) - Diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and PR depression)
  • Brugada patterns (right bundle branch block-like pattern with ST elevations in right precordial leads) seen secondary to electrolyte disturbances like hyperkalemia
  • Hyperkalemia (peaked T waves)

Related Pearl: Sodium Channelopathies

Mutation in Disease
SCN1A Familial hemiplegic migraine type 3
SCN4A

Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis

Potassium aggravated myotonia

Hypokalemic periodic paralysis type 2

Paramyotonia congenita

Congenital myasthenic syndrome
SCN5A

Brugada syndrome

Long QT syndrome type 3
SCN9A Erythromelalgia

questions.text: The following image depicts a sectioned heart extracted from a patient at the time of autopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows multiple, large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves which are seen in infective endocarditis.

Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, the right heart valves may be involved.

Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves.

Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.

Related Pearl: Vegetations in Various Types of Endocarditis

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy comes to the emergency department after a fall. On physical examination, there is pain and swelling in the left wrist region. The X-ray of his wrist joint is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the X-ray showing compression on one side of the radius causing the other side to bend/ buckle suggests a torus fracture.

Torus fracture is also called a buckle fracture. It is caused due to an axial loading force acting along the long axis of a long bone. This results in compression on one side and bending of the other side of the trabecular part of the long bone.

It most commonly occurs at the transition between the metaphysis and diaphysis of the cortex. It is commonly seen occurring at the distal radius in young children. Management includes immobilization and splinting for 3-4 weeks.

The given image indicates the site of the torus fracture:

Greenstick fractures are commonly seen in children. These are incomplete fractures where one side of the cortex is broken but the other side remains intact.

The image given below shows a greenstick fracture:

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A hysterectomy was performed on a 46-year-old multiparous woman who presented with menorrhagia. The images shown below are the transverse section and histology of the specimen. Which of the following is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: Dyspareunia is never seen as a presenting complaint
MRI has no role in the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of hemorrhage. The histological specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis. Hysterectomy is the definitive management of adenomyosis. 

Adenomyosis is also known as endometriosis interna.  Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (selective estrogen receptor modulator) are the main causes for adenomyosis. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years.

Patients with mainly preset with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Dyspareunia can also be present in 10 percent of cases. 

On abdominal examination, a hypogastric mass arising from the pelvis is felt. It usually does not exceed the size of a 14-week uterus. Pelvic examination reveals a uniformly enlarged uterus.

Transvaginal sonography (TVS) and MRI are the imaging modalities caused for diagnosis in which MRI is more specific for diagnosis. 

Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Levonorgestrel- releasing or danazol-loaded intrauterine devices can be used to improve menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with low-grade fever, biphasic stridor, and a barking cough. The following was noted on X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of laryngotracheobronchitis which is caused by Parainfluenza.

Laryngotracheobronchitis, also known as croup, is usually seen in children aged 6 months to 3 years. Children with croup present with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever.  Chest x-ray shows a steeple sign due to subglottic narrowing.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the improvement of upper airway obstruction. 
  • Dexamethasone, by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ), is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are usually not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

Other options:

Option A: Moraxella causes acute otitis media. Children present with otalgia, fever, crying, and irritability.

Option B: Haemophilus influenza causes acute epiglottitis. Children present with an acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia, and drooling.

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus causes tracheitis. Children present with a history of croup, brassy cough, and expiratory or biphasic stridor. X-ray neck shows an irregular tracheal wall.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with gestational diabetes is undergoing vaginal delivery. After the delivery of the head, the obstetrician is unable to deliver the shoulders and classifies it as shoulder dystocia. She performs the following maneuver for delivery. It achieves all of the following except:

choices.text: Rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head
Decrease in angle of pelvic inclination

questions.solution:
The image depicts the McRoberts maneuvre. It does not increase the pelvic dimensions.

McRoberts manoeuvre consists of forceful abduction and flexion of maternal hips and positioning the maternal thighs on to the abdomen. Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.

It is used to free the impacted anterior shoulder through the following:

  • Straightening of the sacrum relative to lumbar vertebrae.
  • Rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head.
  • A decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

questions.text: A child born to a 35-year-old mother was found to have a round face, flat occiput, protruding tongue, and the finding on palm shown. Which of the following is commonly associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings along with the simian crease in the picture suggest Down's syndrome. The most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome is endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

 Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere)

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and a wider gap between first and second toes

A score based on eight signs in the diagnosis of Down's syndrome in the newborn (Hall's criteria)

  • Abundant neck skin
  • Mouth corners turned downwards
  • General hypotonia
  • Flat face
  • Dysplastic ear
  • Epicanthic fold
  • The gap between first and second toes
  • Protruding tongue

The presence of the last 3 points is considered clinically proven Down syndrome. It is suggested that this score should be used routinely for the clinical evaluation of every newborn where the possibility of a diagnosis of Down syndrome has been raised.

Note:

  • Down’s syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability.
  • The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign).
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukemia, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML). 
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life.
  • The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML).
  • The most common hematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM).
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

Image: Features of Down’s syndrome

 

 

Image: Brushfield's spots

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presented with anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. The peripheral smear showed teardrop cells and giant abnormal platelets. Bone marrow biopsy is given below. Which of the following drugs has been approved for use in this condition?
questions.solution:
The bone marrow biopsy shows fibrous tissue suggestive of a diagnosis of myelofibrosis. Fedratinib is approved for use in myelofibrosis. It is a JAK2-selective kinase inhibitor.

Other options:

Rimegepant: Used in migraine.

Avapritinib: Used in GIST

Pitolisant: Used in narcolepsy

questions.text: The optical coherence tomography image in a patient with an acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia is given below. What will be the finding on fundus fluorescein angiography?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and OCT image showing fluid in the subretinal space and is suggestive of central serous retinopathy (CSR). FFA finding in CSR includes smokestack appearance and inkblot/enlarging dot appearance.

CSR is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region. It occurs due to an abnormal choroidal circulation leading to an increase in fluid in the subretinal space.

Two patterns of FFA are seen in CSR. They are:

  • Inkblot pattern or enlarging dot appearance - A small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size.
  • Smokestack appearance - A small hyperfluorescent spot which ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom.

Other options:

  • Stars in sky appearance - Seen in drusens
  • Petaloid appearance - Seen in cystoid macular edema
  • Dual circulation - Seen in choroidal melanoma

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD because of repeated attacks of dermatitis. On examination, ulceration and scarring can be seen on the sun-exposed areas like his face and limbs. He also has reddish-brown discolouration of teeth. On investigation, urine discoloration is observed as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows reddish discoloration of urine known as a port-wine appearance. The clinical scenario describes photosensitivity and erythrodontia (reddish-brown discoloration of teeth). All these features are suggestive of congenital erythropoietic porphyria.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria also known as Gunther's disease is autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocytes, plasma urine, and feces.

The most characteristic presentation is port-wine urine or pink staining of diapers by urine. Reddish-brown teeth are seen under normal light and when illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia (as shown in the image below).

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant fell from the stairs while trying to walk. The parents noticed a swelling in the right thigh and brought the child to the casualty ward. A radiograph revealed a mid-shaft femur fracture. Traction was applied as shown. Identify the skin traction.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is that of Gallows traction.

Gallows traction is used in fracture shaft of femur in children less than 2 years of age. Here skin traction is applied to both legs which are then suspended from a frame, providing just enough traction to keep the buttocks of the child just off the bed.

Other options:

Option B: Russell’s traction or Thomas splint is used to treat fractured femur. After 2–4 weeks, when the fracture has sufficiently progressed, it is replaced by hip spica.

Option C: Perkins' traction is used to treat fractures of the shaft femur in adults. Where a pin is inserted at 3 cm distal to the tibial tuberosity and traction is applied using one Bohler stirrup or two Thomas pin mounts.

Option D: Smith’s traction is used in the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Related Pearl: Some Important Traction and Their Uses

1) Gallow/Bryant traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Fracture shaft femur in children below 2 years

2) Perkin traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Fracture shaft femur in adults

3) Russell’s traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Trochanteric fractures

4) Dunlop/Smith traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Supracondylar fracture humerus

5) Buck's traction: 

  • Most common lower limb traction
  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Femoral fractures, acetabular and hip fractures

6)Crutchfield traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Cervical spine injuries

7) Head halter traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Cervical spine injuries

8) Halo-pelvic traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Scoliosis

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy had fallen on outstretched hands during his soccer match and presented with pain and swelling over his left elbow. His X-ray image is shown below. What is the type of fracture as per Gartland's classification?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray image is suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus (extension type) and Gartland classification is used in this case. The extension type fracture which is displaced with no intact posterior cortex is type 3 as per this classification

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

  • Most commonly seen in children of 5-8 years.
  • Most common type of supracondylar fracture : Extension type> Flexion type.
  • Most common mechanism of injury: Fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension.
  • Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures.

Gartland classification (in children):

  • Type I: Undisplaced
  • Type II: Displaced but posterior cortex is intact
  • Type III: Displaced but no intact posterior cortex and distal fragment could be either displaced:
    • Posteromedial
    • Posterolateral

On examination:

  • Three-point bony landmarks in the elbow are the tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.  Three-point bony relationship is maintained with respect to each other but not with respect to the shaft of the humerus.

Characteristic displacements in Supracondylar fracture(Mnemonic: MID)

  • M- Medial rotation/medial tilt.
  • I- Impaction (proximal shift).
  • D- Dorsal displacement/dorsal tilt.

Nerve injury

  • Most common nerve to be injured in extension type: Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (AMRU)
  • Most common nerve to be injured in the flexion type: Ulnar nerve.

Vessel injury

  • Most common vessel to be injured: Brachial artery.

Complications:

  • Malunion (Most common): Posteromedially displaced fracture  tend to develop Cubitus Varus (Gunstock deformity)
  • Nerve injury: usually neuropraxia, hence transient.
  • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture and compartment syndrome (Most common fracture to cause this in children)
  • Non-union is unknown.

Treatment of Supracondylar fracture:

  • Closed reduction and K-wire fixation.
  • Tractions used: Dunlop and Smith's.

Treatment of Cubitus Varus deformity

  • Lateral closed wedge osteotomy - French
  • Medial open wedge osteotomy - King's

Related Pearl: Named classification systems for fractures and dislocations
