questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with pain and swelling in the small joints of the hand. Her radiograph is as given below. The presence of all of the following radiographic features would point towards a diagnosis of Osteoarthritis except?
questions.solution:
Central/subchondral bone erosions are seen in osteoarthritis. Marginal bone erosions are not a typical feature of osteoarthritis. 

In OA of the hand, the joints involved are the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints(DIP, PIP), and the first carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb).

The nodules palpable in the DIP are called Heberden’s nodes, while those palpable in the PIP are called Bouchard’s nodes.

Radiographic features of osteoarthritis 

  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Subchondral cysts and sclerosis
  • Marginal osteophytes
  • Loose bodies and chondrocalcinosis
  • Central or subchondral erosions give rise to the seagull wing appearance.

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with amenorrhea for the past 4 months. On performing a USG, you notice the presence of twin gestation with a characteristic appearance as shown in the image below. You would identify the type of twin gestation as _________.
questions.solution:
The given USG image depicts the T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation.

In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated by thin amniotic membranes with no intervening chorion. At the point where the amnions meet the placenta a T sign is formed. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester.

Below is an image of T sign:

In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

Below is an image of lamba sign:

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A patient with end-stage renal disease who is currently on dialysis had the following skin lesion. Which of the following is contraindicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding in the given image is calciphylaxis. Warfarin is contraindicated. Infact, it is a risk factor for the development of calciphylaxis.

In calciphylaxis, there is an imbalance of inhibitors and inducers of vascular calcification. This results in excessive calcium deposition in medium-sized arteries, which further leads to necrosis of the part supplied by that vessel. One of the effects of warfarin is to decrease the vitamin K-dependent regeneration of matrix GLA protein which is important in preventing vascular calcification.

Calciphylaxis commonly affects the fatty areas of thighs, abdomen, and buttocks symmetrically. The lesion evolves from purpura to a black eschar.

Management:

  • Supportive and preventive measures including hyperbaric oxygen therapy
  • Debridement and wound care
  • Antibiotics
  • Parathyroidectomy
  • Cinacalcet and phosphate binders
  • Intravenous sodium thiosulphate

questions.text: The following image shows the devices used in the delivery of insulin. Which among the following do not use a needle for the administration of the drug?
questions.solution: The device marked as C is called an insulin jet injector. It uses a needle-free method for the administration of insulin. They have a needle-free nozzle that delivers insulin at a high velocity directly across the skin into the subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came to the hospital with a history of trauma to the ear. On examination, there is swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic
Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of trauma to the ear along with swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the pinna is highly suggestive of hematoma of the auricle (perichondrial hematoma). It does not resolve spontaneously. 

It is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium known as perichondrial space (Option C). It is commonly seen in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players due to blunt trauma and can result in a deformity called cauliflower ear, wrestler's ear, or pugilistic ear (Option B). Severe perichondritis may occur if the hematoma gets infected.

All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics (Option A). Aspiration of the hematoma under strict aseptic precautions and a pressure dressing is done to prevent reaccumulation. Aspiration may need to be repeated. When aspiration fails, incision and drainage should be done.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male with frequent abdominal pain presents to the emergency room. The image of his IV pyelogram is given below. The most likely underlying cause for the finding is:
questions.solution:
The IV pyelogram shows dilated calyces and pelvis of the right kidney with a normal-functioning left kidney. This is due to the presence of a large staghorn calculus (struvite stone) in the pelvicalyceal system of the right kidney. This is caused due to infection with urea-splitting organisms, such as Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, or Enterobacter species.

Staghorn calculi are radio-opaque stones that grow in a branching pattern along the pelvicalyceal system. The above organisms metabolize the urea into ammonium and bicarbonate. Increased metabolism of urea results in alkalinity of the urine, and precipitation of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate - resulting in the formation of struvite stones.

These stones can grow to be very large and can cause significant impairment of renal function. Treatment involves the surgical removal of the stone and antibiotics to treat the infection.

Note: The X-ray also shows renal calyceal stones on the right.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe pain in her buttocks because of the inflammation of the muscle marked in the image below. Which of the following nerves is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis. When piriformis muscle gets inflamed, there is compression of the sciatic nerve which leads to piriformis syndrome characterised by pain along distribution of the sciatic nerve. 

Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. This can occur due to inflammation of the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve which is also known as sciatica. It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle which puts pressure over the underlying the sciatic nerve and causes pain along the distibution of the nerve thereof.

Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.
